{{Thermoreg}}'''Tachyaerobic''' is a term used in [[biology]] to describe the [[muscle]]s of large animals and birds that are able to maintain high levels or physical activity because their hearts make up at least 0.5-0.6 percent of their body mass and maintain high blood pressures.<ref>{{Cite book|title = The Upper Jurassic Morrison Formation: An Interdisciplinary Study : Denver Museum of Natural History, Denver, USA: May 26-28, 1994|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=CLEPeg_SjTcC|publisher = Taylor & Francis|date = 1998-01-01|isbn = 9789056991838|first = Nick|last = Fraser}}</ref> A reptile displaying equal size to a tachyaerobic mammal does not have the same capabilities. Tachyaerobic animals' hearts beat more quickly, produce more oxygen, and distribute blood at a quicker rate than reptiles.
The use of tachyaerobic muscles is important to animals such as [[giraffes]] that need blood circulated through a large body size quickly.

{{short description|Proteins}}
{{Pfam_box | Symbol = BCCT | Name = BCCT family transporter | image = BetP 3po3.png | width = | caption = BetP (betaine transporter) from ''Cornyebacterium glutamicum''. [[Protein Data Bank|PDB]] 3p03 | Pfam= PF02028 | InterPro= IPR000060 | SMART= | Prosite = | SCOP = | TCDB = 2.A.15 | OPM family= 64 | OPM protein= 4ain | PDB= }}
Proteins of the '''Betaine/Carnitine/Choline Transporter''' ('''BCCT''') '''family''' are found in [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria]] and [[archaea]]. The BCCT family is a member a large group of secondary transporters, the [[APC Superfamily|APC superfamily]]. Their common functional feature is that they all transport molecules with a quaternary ammonium group [R-N (CH<sub>3</sub>)<sub>3</sub>]. The BCCT family proteins vary in length between 481 and 706 amino [[acyl]] residues and possess 12 putative [[Transmembrane segment|transmembrane α-helical spanners]] (TMSs). The x-ray structures reveal two 5 TMS repeats with the total number of TMSs being 10. These porters catalyze bidirectional [[uniport]] or are energized by [[Proton-motive force|pmf-driven]] or smf-driven proton or sodium ion [[symport]], respectively, or else by substrate:substrate [[antiport]]. Some of these permeases exhibit osmosensory and osmoregulatory properties inherent to their polypeptide chains.<ref name=TCDB>{{cite web|last1=Saier|first1=MH Jr.|title=2.A.15 The Betaine/Carnitine/Choline Transporter (BCCT) Family|url=http://tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.15|website=Transporter Classification Database|publisher=Saier Lab Bioinformatics Group}}</ref>
==Structure== The structures of the sodium-independent carnitine/butyrobetaine antiporter CaiT from ''Proteus mirabilis'' (PmCaiT) ({{PDB2|4M8J}}) and from ''E. coli'' (EcCaiT)({{PDB2|3HFX}}) were determined.<ref name=Schulze>{{cite journal|last1=Schulze|first1=S|last2=Köster|first2=S|last3=Geldmacher|first3=U|last4=Terwisscha van Scheltinga|first4=AC|last5=Kühlbrandt|first5=W|title=Structural basis of Na(+)-independent and cooperative substrate/product antiport in CaiT.|journal=Nature|date=September 9, 2010|volume=467|issue=7312|pages=233–6|doi=10.1038/nature09310|pmid=20829798|url=https://pure.rug.nl/ws/files/2585961/2010NatureSchulze.pdf}}</ref>
Most members of the BCCT family are Na<sup>+</sup>- or H<sup>+</sup>-dependent, whereas EcCaiT is a Na<sup>+</sup>- and H<sup>+</sup>-independent substrate:product antiporter. The three-dimensional architecture of CaiT resembles that of the Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent transporters [http://www.tcdb.org/search/index.php?query=LeuT&type=system LeuT] and [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.15.1.10 BetP], but in CaiT, a methionine sulphur takes the place of the Na<sup>+</sup> to coordinate the substrate in the central transport site, accounting for Na<sup>+</sup> independence. Both CaiT structures ({{PDB2|SWSW}}, {{PDB2|4M8J}}) show the fully open, inward-facing conformation, and thus complete the set of functional states that describe the alternating access mechanism. EcCaiT ({{PDB2|SWSX}}, {{PDB2|3HFX}}) contains two bound butyrobetaine substrate molecules, one in the central transport site, the other in an extracellular binding pocket. In the structure of PmCaiT, a tryptophan side chain occupies the transport site, and access to the extracellular site is blocked. Binding of both substrates to CaiT reconstituted into proteoliposomes is cooperative, with [[Hill coefficient]]s of up to 1.7, indicating that the extracellular site is regulatory. Schulze et al. (2010) proposed a mechanism whereby the occupied regulatory site increases the binding affinity of the transport site and initiates substrate translocation.<ref name=Schulze/> Glycine betaine transporters have been found to contain a conserved region with four tryptophans in their central region.<ref name="PUB00002302">{{cite journal |vauthors=Kempf B, Bremer E, Kappes RM |title=Three transport systems for the osmoprotectant glycine betaine operate in Bacillus subtilis: characterization of OpuD |journal=J. Bacteriol. |volume=178 |issue=17 |pages=5071–5079 |year=1996 |pmid=8752321 |pmc=178300|doi=10.1128/jb.178.17.5071-5079.1996 }}</ref>
==Function== Most secondary-active transporters transport their substrates using an [[electrochemical ion gradient]], but the carnitine transporter (CaiT) is an ion-independent, L-carnitine/gamma-butyrobetaine antiporter. Crystal structures of CaiT from ''E. coli'' and ''Proteus mirabilis'' revealed the inverted five-transmembrane-helix repeat similar to that in the amino acid/Na<sup>+</sup> symporter, LeuT. Kalayil et al. (2013) showed that mutations of arginine 262 (R262) made CaiT Na<sup>+</sup>-dependent with increased transport activity in the presence of a membrane potential, in agreement with substrate/Na<sup>+</sup> cotransport. R262 also plays a role in substrate binding by stabilizing the partly unwound TM1' helix.<ref name=Kalayil>{{cite journal|last1=Kalayil|first1=S|last2=Schulze|first2=S|last3=Kühlbrandt|first3=W|title=Arginine oscillation explains Na+ independence in the substrate/product antiporter CaiT.|date=October 22, 2013|volume=110|issue=43|pages=17296–301|doi=10.1073/pnas.1309071110|pmid=24101465|pmc=3808595|journal=Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A.}}</ref>
Modeling CaiT from ''P. mirabilis'' in the outward-open and closed states on the corresponding structures of the related symporter BetP revealed alternating orientations of the buried R262 side chain, which mimic sodium binding and unbinding in the Na<sup>+</sup>-coupled substrate symporters. A similar mechanism may be operative in other Na<sup>+</sup>/H<sup>+</sup>-independent transporters, in which a positively charged amino acid replaces the cotransported cation. The oscillation of the R262 side chain in CaiT indicates how a positive charge triggers the change between outward-open and inward-open conformations.<ref name=Kalayil />
==Transport reactions== The generalized transport reactions catalyzed by members of the BCCT family are:<ref name=TCDB />
::Substrate (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) → Substrate (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in)
::Substrate (out) + Na<sup>+</sup> (out) → Substrate (in) + Na<sup>+</sup> (in)
::Substrate-1 (out) + Substrate-2 (in) → Substrate-1 (in) + Substrate-2 (out)
::Substrate (out) ⇌ Substrate (in)
:::Substrate = a quaternary amine
==Other betaine transporters== *The mammalian betaine transporter: [[Sodium- and chloride-dependent betaine transporter]]

{{Pfam_box | Symbol = APC | Name = | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam = PF0034 | Pfam_clan = | InterPro = IPR004841 | SMART = | PROSITE = | SCOP = | TCDB = 2.A.3 | OPM family = 64 | OPM protein = 3gia | PDB = }}
The '''Amino Acid-Polyamine-Organocation (APC) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.3 TC# 2.A.3]) of transport proteins includes members that function as solute:cation symporters and solute:solute antiporters.<ref name="Saier 2000">{{cite journal | vauthors = Saier MH | title = Families of transmembrane transporters selective for amino acids and their derivatives | journal = Microbiology | volume = 146 ( Pt 8) | issue = 8 | pages = 1775–95 | date = August 2000 | pmid = 10931885 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-146-8-1775 }}</ref><ref name="Wong 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Wong FH, Chen JS, Reddy V, Day JL, Shlykov MA, Wakabayashi ST, Saier MH | title = The amino acid-polyamine-organocation superfamily | journal = Journal of Molecular Microbiology and Biotechnology | volume = 22 | issue = 2 | pages = 105–13 | date = 2012 | pmid = 22627175 | doi = 10.1159/000338542 }}</ref><ref name=Schweikhard>{{cite book | vauthors = Schweikhard ES, Ziegler CM | title = Amino acid secondary transporters: toward a common transport mechanism | journal = Current Topics in Membranes | volume = 70 | pages = 1–28 | date = 2012 | pmid = 23177982 | doi = 10.1016/B978-0-12-394316-3.00001-6 | isbn = 9780123943163 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Perland E, Fredriksson R | title = Classification Systems of Secondary Active Transporters | journal = Trends in Pharmacological Sciences | volume = 38 | issue = 3 | pages = 305–315 | date = March 2017 | pmid = 27939446 | doi = 10.1016/j.tips.2016.11.008 }}</ref> They occur in bacteria, archaea, fungi, unicellular eukaryotic protists, slime molds, plants and animals.<ref name="Saier 2000"/> They vary in length, being as small as 350 residues and as large as 850 residues. The smaller proteins are generally of prokaryotic origin while the larger ones are of eukaryotic origin. Most of them possess twelve transmembrane α-helical spanners but have a re-entrant loop involving TMSs 2 and 3.<ref name=Gasol>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gasol E, Jiménez-Vidal M, Chillarón J, Zorzano A, Palacín M | title = Membrane topology of system xc- light subunit reveals a re-entrant loop with substrate-restricted accessibility | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 30 | pages = 31228–36 | date = July 2004 | pmid = 15151999 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M402428200 }}</ref><ref name=TCDB>{{cite web|last1=Saier|first1=MH Jr.|title=2.A.3 The Amino Acid-Polyamine-Organocation (APC) Superfamily|url=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3|website=Transporter Classification Database|publisher=Saier Lab Bioinformatics Group / SDSC}}</ref> The [[APC Superfamily]] was established to encompass a wider range of homologues.
==Members of APC Family==
Members of one subfamily within the APC family ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.9#2.A.3.9 SGP; TC# 2.A.3.9]) are amino acid receptors rather than transporters <ref name=Cabrera>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cabrera-Martinez RM, Tovar-Rojo F, Vepachedu VR, Setlow P | title = Effects of overexpression of nutrient receptors on germination of spores of Bacillus subtilis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 185 | issue = 8 | pages = 2457–64 | date = April 2003 | pmid = 12670969 | pmc = 152624 | doi = 10.1128/jb.185.8.2457-2464.2003 }}</ref> and are truncated at their C-termini, relative to the transporters, having 10 TMSs.<ref name=Jack>{{cite journal | vauthors = Jack DL, Paulsen IT, Saier MH | title = The amino acid/polyamine/organocation (APC) superfamily of transporters specific for amino acids, polyamines and organocations | journal = Microbiology | volume = 146 ( Pt 8) | issue = 8 | pages = 1797–814 | date = August 2000 | pmid = 10931886 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-146-8-1797 }}</ref>
The eukaryotic members of another subfamily ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.3#2.A.3.3 CAT; TC# 2.A.3.3]) and the members of a prokaryotic subfamily ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.11#2.A.3.11 AGT; TC #2.A.3.11]) have 14 TMSs.<ref name=Lorca>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lorca G, Winnen B, Saier MH | title = Identification of the L-aspartate transporter in Bacillus subtilis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 185 | issue = 10 | pages = 3218–22 | date = May 2003 | pmid = 12730183 | pmc = 154055 | doi = 10.1128/jb.185.10.3218-3222.2003 }}</ref>
The larger eukaryotic and archaeal proteins possess N- and C-terminal hydrophilic extensions. Some animal proteins, for example, those in the LAT subfamily ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8#2.A.3.8 TC# 2.A.3.8]) including [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.2 ASUR4 (gbY12716)] and [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.3 SPRM1 (gbL25068)] associate with a type 1 transmembrane glycoprotein that is essential for insertion or activity of the permease and forms a disulfide bridge with it. These glycoproteins include the CD98 heavy chain protein of ''Mus musculus (gbU25708)'' and the orthologous 4F2 cell surface antigen heavy chain of ''Homo sapiens (spP08195).'' The latter protein is required for the activity of the cystine/glutamate antiporter ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.5 2.A.3.8.5]), which maintains cellular redox balance and cysteine/glutathione levels.<ref name="Sato 2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Sato H, Shiiya A, Kimata M, Maebara K, Tamba M, Sakakura Y, Makino N, Sugiyama F, Yagami K, Moriguchi T, Takahashi S, Bannai S | title = Redox imbalance in cystine/glutamate transporter-deficient mice | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 280 | issue = 45 | pages = 37423–9 | date = November 2005 | pmid = 16144837 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.m506439200 }}</ref> They are members of the rBAT family of mammalian proteins ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=8.A.9 TC #8.A.9]).
Two APC family members, LAT1 and LAT2 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.7 TC #2.A.3.8.7]), transport a neurotoxicant, the methylmercury-L-cysteine complex, by [[molecular mimicry]].<ref name=SimWillis>{{cite journal | vauthors = Simmons-Willis TA, Koh AS, Clarkson TW, Ballatori N | title = Transport of a neurotoxicant by molecular mimicry: the methylmercury-L-cysteine complex is a substrate for human L-type large neutral amino acid transporter (LAT) 1 and LAT2 | journal = The Biochemical Journal | volume = 367 | issue = Pt 1 | pages = 239–46 | date = October 2002 | pmid = 12117417 | pmc = 1222880 | doi = 10.1042/bj20020841 }}</ref>
Hip1 of ''S. cerevisiae'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.1.5 TC #2.A.3.1.5]) has been implicated in heavy metal transport.
===Subfamilies===
Subfamilies of the APC family, and the proteins in these families, can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.9 Transporter Classification Database]:<ref name=TCDB/>
*2.A.3.1: The Amino Acid Transporter (AAT) Family *2.A.3.2: The Basic Amino Acid/Polyamine Antiporter (APA) Family *2.A.3.3: The Cationic Amino Acid Transporter (CAT) Family *2.A.3.4: The Amino Acid/Choline Transporter (ACT) Family *2.A.3.5: The Ethanolamine Transporter (EAT) Family *2.A.3.6: The Archaeal/Bacterial Transporter (ABT) Family *2.A.3.7: The Glutamate:GABA Antiporter (GGA) Family *2.A.3.8: The L-type Amino Acid Transporter (LAT) Family (Many LAT family members function as heterooligomers with rBAT and/or 4F2hc (TC #8.A.9)) *2.A.3.9: The Spore Germination Protein (SGP) Family *2.A.3.10: The Yeast Amino Acid Transporter (YAT) Family *2.A.3.11: The Aspartate/Glutamate Transporter (AGT) Family *2.A.3.12: The Polyamine:H+ Symporter (PHS) Family *2.A.3.13: The Amino Acid Efflux (AAE) Family *2.A.3.14: The Unknown APC-1 (U-APC1) Family *2.A.3.15: The Unknown APC-2 (U-APC2) Family
==Structure and Function== Based on 3-D structures of APC superfamily members, Rudnick (2011) has proposed the pathway for transport and suggested a "''rocking bundle"'' mechanism.<ref name="TCDB" /><ref name="Forrest">{{cite journal | vauthors = Forrest LR, Rudnick G | title = The rocking bundle: a mechanism for ion-coupled solute flux by symmetrical transporters | journal = Physiology | volume = 24 | issue = 6 | pages = 377–86 | date = December 2009 | pmid = 19996368 | pmc = 3012352 | doi = 10.1152/physiol.00030.2009 }}</ref><ref name="Rudnick 2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rudnick G | title = Cytoplasmic permeation pathway of neurotransmitter transporters | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 50 | issue = 35 | pages = 7462–75 | date = September 2011 | pmid = 21774491 | pmc = 3164596 | doi = 10.1021/bi200926b }}</ref>
===Transport Reactions=== Transport reactions generally catalyzed by APC Superfamily members include:<ref name=TCDB/>
::Solute:proton symport Solute (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) → Solute (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in).
::Solute:solute antiport Solute-1 (out) + Solute-2 (in) ⇌ Solute-1 (in) + Solute-2 (out).

In ecology, '''sulfide intrusion''' refers to an excess of [[sulfide]] molecules (S<sup>2-</sup>) in the soil that interfere with plant growth, often [[seagrass]].<ref>{{Citation |title=Iron Additions Reduce Sulfide Intrusion and Reverse Seagrass (Posidonia oceanica) Decline in Carbonate Sediments | author=Núria Marbà |display-authors=etal | journal=Ecosystems | year=2007 | volume=10 | issue=5 | pages=745–756 | doi=10.1007/s10021-007-9053-8 | hdl=10261/88858 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title=Sulfide intrusion in the tropical seagrasses Thalassia testudinum and Syringodium filiforme | author=Marianne Holmer |display-authors=etal | journal=Estuarine, Coastal and Shelf Science | year=2009 | volume=85 | issue=2 | pages=319–326 | doi=10.1016/j.ecss.2009.08.015 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title=Sulfide Intrusion and Detoxification in the Seagrass Zostera marina | author=Harald Hasler-Sheetal and Marianne Holmer | journal=PLoS ONE | year=2015 | volume=10 | issue=6 | pages=e0129136 | doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0129136 | pmid=26030258 | pmc=4452231 }}</ref>
[[Seagrass]] bed sediment (soil) is typically anoxic, containing a reduced form of sulfur: [[hydrogen sulfide]] (H<sub>2</sub>S). H<sub>2</sub>S is a phytotoxin that results from [[anaerobic digestion]], the [[decomposition]] of [[organic matter]] in the absence of oxygen. However, seagrass can persist in this environment because of physiological adaptations, as well as functional adaptations of other organisms in the ecosystem. For example, bivalves (clams) in the family [[Lucinidae]] host symbiotic bacteria that oxidize sulfides. Lucinid bivalves' gills house the bacteria, and the siphon supplies the bacteria and surrounding [[pore water]] with oxygenated water from above the sediment. Bacterial oxidation of the sulfides results in sulfates, reducing toxicity.<ref>{{Citation |title=Lucinid clam influence on the biogeochemistry of the seagrass Thalassia testudinum sediments | author=L.K. Reynolds, P. Berg, and J.C. Zieman | journal=Estuaries and Coasts | year=2007 | volume=30 | issue=3 | pages=482–490 | doi=10.1007/bf02819394}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |title=A Three-Stage Symbiosis Forms the Foundation of Seagrass Ecosystems | author=Tjisse van der Heide |display-authors=etal | journal=Science | year=2012 | volume=336 | issue=6087 | pages=1432–1434 | doi=10.1126/science.1219973 | url=https://www.rug.nl/research/portal/en/publications/a-threestage-symbiosis-forms-the-foundation-of-seagrass-ecosystems(23625acb-7ec0-4480-98d7-fad737d7d4fe).html | pmid=22700927}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{Infobox protein family | Symbol = Xan_ur_permease | Name = Xanthine/uracil/vitamin C permease | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam = PF00860 | Pfam_clan = CL0062 | InterPro = IPR006043 | SMART = | PROSITE = PDOC00860 | MEROPS = | SCOP = | TCDB = 2.A.40 | OPM family = 64 | OPM protein = 3qe7 | CAZy = | CDD = }} The '''Nucleobase cation symporter-2''' (NCS2) family, also called the '''Nucleobase ascorbate transporter''' (NAT) family,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Karatza P, Panos P, Georgopoulou E, Frillingos S | title = Cysteine-scanning analysis of the nucleobase-ascorbate transporter signature motif in YgfO permease of Escherichia coli: Gln-324 and Asn-325 are essential, and Ile-329-Val-339 form an alpha-helix | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 281 | issue = 52 | pages = 39881–90 | date = Dec 2006 | pmid = 17077086 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M605748200 }}</ref> consists of over 1000 sequenced proteins derived from [[gram-negative bacteria|gram-negative]] and [[gram-positive bacteria]], archaea, fungi, plants and animals. The NCS2/NAT family is a member of the [[APC Superfamily]] of secondary carriers.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | vauthors = Wong FH, Chen JS, Reddy V, Day JL, Shlykov MA, Wakabayashi ST, Saier MH | title = The amino acid-polyamine-organocation superfamily | journal = Journal of Molecular Microbiology and Biotechnology | volume = 22 | issue = 2 | pages = 105–13 | date = 2012-01-01 | pmid = 22627175 | doi = 10.1159/000338542 }}</ref> Of the five known families of transporters that act on nucleobases, NCS2/NAT is the only one that is most widespread.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Frillingos S | title = Insights to the evolution of Nucleobase-Ascorbate Transporters (NAT/NCS2 family) from the Cys-scanning analysis of xanthine permease XanQ | journal = International Journal of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology | volume = 3 | issue = 3 | pages = 250–72 | date = 2012-01-01 | pmid = 23097742 | pmc = 3476789 }}</ref> Many functionally characterized members are specific for nucleobases including both purines and pyrimidines, but others are purine-specific. However, two closely related rat/human members of the family, SVCT1 and SVCT2, localized to different tissues of the body, co-transport L-ascorbate ([[vitamin C]]) and Na<sup>+</sup> with a high degree of specificity and high affinity for the vitamin.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Diallinas G, Gournas C | title = Structure-function relationships in the nucleobase-ascorbate transporter (NAT) family: lessons from model microbial genetic systems | journal = Channels | volume = 2 | issue = 5 | pages = 363–72 | date = 2008-10-01 | pmid = 18981714 | doi=10.4161/chan.2.5.6902}}</ref> Clustering of NCS2/NAT family members on the phylogenetic tree is complex, with bacterial proteins and eukaryotic proteins each falling into at least three distinct clusters. The plant and animal proteins cluster loosely together, but the fungal proteins branch from one of the three bacterial clusters forming a tighter grouping.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gournas C, Papageorgiou I, Diallinas G | title = The nucleobase-ascorbate transporter (NAT) family: genomics, evolution, structure-function relationships and physiological role | journal = Molecular BioSystems | volume = 4 | issue = 5 | pages = 404–16 | date = May 2008 | pmid = 18414738 | doi = 10.1039/b719777b }}</ref> ''E. coli'' possesses four distantly related paralogous members of the NCS2 family.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url = http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40|title = 2.A.40 The Nucleobase/Ascorbate Transporter (NAT) or Nucleobase:Cation Symporter-2 (NCS2) Family|date = |access-date = |website = Transporter Classification Database|publisher = Saier Lab Bioinformatics Group / SDSC|last = Saier|first = MH Jr. | name-list-format = vanc }}</ref>
==Structure== Proteins of the NCS2 family are 414–650 amino acyl residues in length and probably possess 14 TMSs. Lu et al. (2011) have concluded from x-ray crystallography that UraA ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40.1.1 2.A.40.1.1]) has 14 TMSs with two 7 TMS inverted repeats.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal | vauthors = Lu F, Li S, Jiang Y, Jiang J, Fan H, Lu G, Deng D, Dang S, Zhang X, Wang J, Yan N | title = Structure and mechanism of the uracil transporter UraA | journal = Nature | volume = 472 | issue = 7342 | pages = 243–6 | date = Apr 2011 | pmid = 21423164 | doi = 10.1038/nature09885 }}</ref> Uracil is located at the interface between the two domains.<ref name=":0" />
===Crystal structures=== Uracil permease, UraA UraA with bound uracil at 2.8Å resolution {{PDB|3QE7}}.
==Transport reaction== The generalized transport reactions catalyzed by proteins of the NAT/NCS2 family are:<ref name=":1" />
:Nucleobase (out) H<sup>+</sup> (out) → Nucleobase (in) H<sup>+</sup> (in).
:Ascorbate (out) Na<sup>+</sup> (out) → Ascorbate (in) Na<sup>+</sup> (in).
==Characterized proteins== Several proteins make up the NCS2/NAT family. A full list of these proteins can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40.7 Transporter Classification Database]. A few types of proteins that make up the NCS2/NAT family include:<ref name=":1" />
* Xanthine [[permease]]s, including PbuX (XanP) of ''Bacillus subtilis'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40.3.1 TC# 2.A.40.3.1]), involved in cellular xanthine [[transport]].<ref name="pmid9098051">{{cite journal | vauthors = Christiansen LC, Schou S, Nygaard P, Saxild HH | title = Xanthine metabolism in Bacillus subtilis: characterization of the xpt-pbuX operon and evidence for purine- and nitrogen-controlled expression of genes involved in xanthine salvage and catabolism | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 179 | issue = 8 | pages = 2540–50 | date = Apr 1997 | pmid = 9098051 | pmc = 179002 | doi = 10.1128/jb.179.8.2540-2550.1997}}</ref> * Uric acid permeases, including PucJ of ''Bacillus subtilus'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40.3.2 TC# 2.A.40.3.2]), which promotes uptake of uric acid into the cell in limiting-nitrogen conditions.<ref name="pmid11344136">{{cite journal | vauthors = Schultz AC, Nygaard P, Saxild HH | title = Functional analysis of 14 genes that constitute the purine catabolic pathway in Bacillus subtilis and evidence for a novel regulon controlled by the PucR transcription activator | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 183 | issue = 11 | pages = 3293–302 | date = Jun 2001 | pmid = 11344136 | pmc = 99626 | doi = 10.1128/JB.183.11.3293-3302.2001 }}</ref> * [[Uracil]] permeases, including UraA of ''E. coli'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40.1.1 TC# 2.A.40.1.1]), which facilitates Uracil uptake.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref name="pmid8206848">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ghim SY, Neuhard J | title = The pyrimidine biosynthesis operon of the thermophile Bacillus caldolyticus includes genes for uracil phosphoribosyltransferase and uracil permease | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 176 | issue = 12 | pages = 3698–707 | date = Jun 1994 | pmid = 8206848 | pmc = 205559 | doi = 10.1128/jb.176.12.3698-3707.1994}}</ref> * Pyrimidine permeases, including RutG of ''E. coli'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40.1.3 TC# 2.A.40.1.3]) <ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Loh KD, Gyaneshwar P, Markenscoff Papadimitriou E, Fong R, Kim KS, Parales R, Zhou Z, Inwood W, Kustu S | title = A previously undescribed pathway for pyrimidine catabolism | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 103 | issue = 13 | pages = 5114–9 | date = Mar 2006 | pmid = 16540542 | pmc = 1458803 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0600521103 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kim KS, Pelton JG, Inwood WB, Andersen U, Kustu S, Wemmer DE | title = The Rut pathway for pyrimidine degradation: novel chemistry and toxicity problems | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 192 | issue = 16 | pages = 4089–102 | date = Aug 2010 | pmid = 20400551 | pmc = 2916427 | doi = 10.1128/JB.00201-10 }}</ref> * Purine permeases, including YcpX of ''Clostridium perfringens'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.40.2.1 TC# 2.A.40.2.1])

The '''Hydroxy/Aromatic Amino Acid Permease (HAAAP) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42 TC# 2.A.42]) is a member of the large [[APC Superfamily|Amino Acid-Polyamine-OrganoCation (APC) Superfamily]] of secondary carriers. Members of the HAAAP family all function in amino acid uptake. Homologues are present in a large number of [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria]], with at least one member classified from archaea ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42.1.7 TC# 2.A.42.1.7], ''[[Thermococcus barophilus]]'')''.''
==Structure== Proteins of the HAAAP family possess 403-443 amino acyl residues and exhibit eleven putative or established transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs). These proteins exhibit topological features common to the eukaryotic [[AAAP Family|amino acid/auxin permease (AAAP) family]] ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.18 TC# 2.A.18]). These proteins also exhibit limited sequence similarity with some of the AAAP family members. A phylogenetic relationship has been proposed between members of the HAAAP family and APC family since they exhibit limited sequence similarity with one another.
As of early 2016, there is no crystal structural data available for members of the HAAAP family in [[Protein Data Bank|RCSB]].
==Members of the HAAAP Family== The HAAAP family includes three well-characterized aromatic amino acid:H<sup>+</sup> symport permeases of ''E. coli'': a high affinity tryptophan-specific permease, Mtr ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42.1.2 TC# 2.A.42.1.2]), a low affinity tryptophan permease, TnaB ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42.1.3 TC# 2.A.42.1.3]), and a tyrosine-specific permease, TyrP ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42.1.1 TC# 2.A.42.1.1]), as well as two well-characterized hydroxy amino acid permeases, the serine permease, SdaC ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42.2.1 TC# 2.A.42.2.1]), of ''E. coli'', and the threonine permease, TdcC ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42.2.2 TC# 2.A.42.2.2]), of ''E. coli''.
SdaC of ''E. coli'' (TC# 2.A.42.2.1) is also called DcrA, and together with a periplasmic protein DcrB (P37620), has been reported to play a role in phage DNA uptake in conjunction with an outer membrane receptor of the OMR family ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.B.14 TC# 1.B.14]). Thus, FhuA (TC #1.B.14.1.4) transports phage T5 DNA while BtuB ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.B.14.3.1 TC# 1.B.14.3.1]) transports phage C1 DNA (Samsonov et al., 2002). DcuB is a putative lipoprotein found only in enteric bacteria.
All members of the HAAAP family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.42.2 Transporter Classification Database].
==Transport Reaction== The generalized transport reaction catalyzed by proteins of the HAAAP family is:
Amino acid (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) → Amino acid (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in).

{{Pfam_box | Symbol = Transp_cyt_pur | Name = Permease for cytosine/purines, uracil, thiamine, allantoin | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam= PF02133 | InterPro= IPR001248 | SMART= | Prosite = | SCOP = | TCDB = 2.A.39 | OPM family= 64 | OPM protein= 2x79 | CDD = cd10323 | PDB= }} The '''Nucleobase:Cation Symporter-1 (NCS1) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39 TC# 2.A.39]) consists of over 1000 currently sequenced proteins derived from [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria|Gram-positive]] bacteria, [[archaea]], fungi and plants. These proteins function as transporters for nucleobases including [[purines]] and [[pyrimidines]]. Members of this family possess twelve transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs). At least some of them have been shown to function in uptake by substrate:H<sup>+</sup> symport mechanism.
==Phylogeny== The bacterial and yeast proteins are widely divergent and do not cluster closely on the NCS1 family phylogenetic tree. ''B. subtilis'' possesses two paralogues of the NCS1 family, and ''S. cerevisiae'' has several. Two of the yeast proteins (Dal4 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39.3.1 TC# 2.A.39.3.1]) and Fur4 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39.3.2 TC# 2.A.39.3.2])) cluster tightly together. Three other ''S. cerevisiae'' proteins, one of which is the thiamin permease, Thi10 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39.4.1 TC# 2.A.39.4.1]), and another of which is the nicotinamide riboside transporter, Nrt1 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39.4.2 TC# 2.A.39.4.2]),<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Belenky PA, Moga TG, Brenner C | title = Saccharomyces cerevisiae YOR071C encodes the high affinity nicotinamide riboside transporter Nrt1 | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 283 | issue = 13 | pages = 8075–9 | date = March 2008 | pmid = 18258590 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.C800021200 }}</ref> also cluster tightly together. The latter three proteins are likely to be closely related thiamin permease isoforms. The yeast cytosine-purine and vitamin B6 transporters cluster loosely together (24% identity; e-50).<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Stolz J, Vielreicher M | title = Tpn1p, the plasma membrane vitamin B6 transporter of Saccharomyces cerevisiae | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 278 | issue = 21 | pages = 18990–6 | date = May 2003 | pmid = 12649274 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M300949200 }}</ref> The bacterial proteins are derived from several Gram-negative and Gram-positive species. These proteins exhibit limited sequence similarity with the xanthine permease, PbuX ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39.4.1 TC# 2.A.39.4.1]), of ''Bacillus subtilis'' which is a member of the [[Nucleobase cation symporter-2|NCS2 family]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url = http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39#ref34543773|title = 2.A.39 The Nucleobase:Cation Symporter-1 (NCS1) Family|date = |access-date = |website = Transporter Classification Database|publisher = Saier Lab Bioinformatics Group / SDSC|last = Saier|first = MH Jr.}}</ref>
==Structure and Function== Proteins of the NCS1 family are 419-635 amino acyl residues long and possess twelve putative transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs). At least some of them have been shown to function in uptake by substrate:H<sup>+</sup> symport. In these respects, and with respect to substrate specificity, these proteins resemble the symporters of the [[Nucleobase cation symporter-2|NCS2 family]], providing further evidence that the two families represent distant constituents of a single superfamily, the [[APC Superfamily]]. The two families probably arose by an early gene duplication event that occurred long before divergence of the three major kingdoms of life. It is possible that they are distant constituents of the MFS (2.A.1).<ref name=":2" />
The nucleobase-cation-symport-1 (NCS1) transporters are essential components of salvage pathways for [[nucleobase]]s and related metabolites. Weyand et al. (2008) reported the 2.85-angstrom resolution structure of the NCS1 benzyl-hydantoin transporter, Mhp1 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.39.3.6 TC# 2.A.39.3.6]), from ''Microbacterium liquefaciens''.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | vauthors = Weyand S, Shimamura T, Yajima S, Suzuki S, Mirza O, Krusong K, Carpenter EP, Rutherford NG, Hadden JM, O'Reilly J, Ma P, Saidijam M, Patching SG, Hope RJ, Norbertczak HT, Roach PC, Iwata S, Henderson PJ, Cameron AD | title = Structure and molecular mechanism of a nucleobase-cation-symport-1 family transporter | journal = Science | volume = 322 | issue = 5902 | pages = 709–13 | date = October 2008 | pmid = 18927357 | pmc = 2885439 | doi = 10.1126/science.1164440 }}</ref> This structure (and related structures) are available through [https://web.archive.org/web/20150418160606/http://www.rcsb.org/pdb/home/home.do RCSB] ({{PDB|2JLN}}, {{PDB2|2X79}}, {{PDB2|4D1A}}, {{PDB2|4D1B}}, {{PDB2|4D1C}}, {{PDB2|4D1D}}). Mhp1 contains 12 transmembrane helices, 10 of which are arranged in two inverted repeats of five helices. The structures of the outward-facing open and substrate-bound occluded conformations were solved, showing how the outward-facing cavity closes upon binding of substrate.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kazmier K, Sharma S, Islam SM, Roux B, Mchaourab HS | title = Conformational cycle and ion-coupling mechanism of the Na+/hydantoin transporter Mhp1 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 111 | issue = 41 | pages = 14752–7 | date = October 2014 | pmid = 25267652 | pmc = 4205665 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1410431111 }}</ref> Comparisons with the leucine transporter LeuT(Aa) and the galactose transporter vSGLT reveal that the outward- and inward-facing cavities are symmetrically arranged on opposite sides of the membrane. The reciprocal opening and closing of these cavities is synchronized by the inverted repeat helices 3 and 8, providing the structural basis of the alternating access model for membrane transport.<ref name=":0" />
===Substrates=== NCS1 proteins are H<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> symporters specific for the uptake of purines, pyrimidines and related metabolites. Krypotou et al. 2015 studied the origin, diversification and substrate specificities of fungal NCS1 transporters, suggesting that the two fungal NCS1 subfamilies, Fur and Fcy, and plant homologues, originated through independent horizontal transfers from prokaryotes.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | vauthors = Krypotou E, Evangelidis T, Bobonis J, Pittis AA, Gabaldón T, Scazzocchio C, Mikros E, Diallinas G | title = Origin, diversification and substrate specificity in the family of NCS1/FUR transporters | journal = Molecular Microbiology | volume = 96 | issue = 5 | pages = 927–50 | date = June 2015 | pmid = 25712422 | doi = 10.1111/mmi.12982 }}</ref> Expansion by gene duplication led to functional diversification of fungal NCS1 porters. They characterized all Fur proteins in Aspergillus nidulans. Homology modelling, substrate docking, molecular dynamics and systematic mutational analysis in three Fur transporters with distinct specificities identified residues critical for function and specificity, located within a major substrate binding site, in transmembrane segments TMS1, TMS3, TMS6 and TMS8. They predicted and confirmed that residues determining substrate specificity are located not only in the major substrate binding site, but also in a putative outward-facing selectivity gate. Their evolutionary and structure-function analyses led to the concept that selective channel-like gates may contribute to substrate specificity.<ref name=":1" />
==Transport Reaction== The generalized transport reaction catalyzed by NCS1 family permeases is:<ref name=":2" />
:Nucleobase or Vitamin (out) + H<sup>+</sup> (out) → Nucleobase or Vitamin (in) + H<sup>+</sup> (in)

[[File:Salt ponds SF Bay (dro!d).jpg|thumb|right|260px|Purple [[bacteriorhodopsin]] in [[Halobacteria]] at [[Cargill]]'s [[salt evaporation ponds]] in [[San Francisco Bay]], located at [[Newark, California]]<ref name="Oren2002">{{cite journal|last1=Oren|first1=Aharon|title=Molecular ecology of extremely halophilic Archaea and Bacteria|journal=FEMS Microbiology Ecology|volume=39|issue=1|year=2002|pages=1–7|url=http://femsec.oxfordjournals.org/content/39/1/1.full|issn=0168-6496|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6941.2002.tb00900.x|pmid=19709178}}</ref>]]
{{Pfam_box | Symbol = Bac_rhodopsin | Name = Bacteriorhodopsin-like protein | image =1m0l_opm.png | width = 200px | caption =Bacteriorhodopsin trimer | Pfam= PF01036 | InterPro= IPR001425 | SMART= | PROSITE = PDOC00291 | SCOP = 2brd | TCDB = 3.E.1 | OPM family= 6 | OPM protein= 1vgo | PDB= }}
'''Microbial rhodopsins''', also known as '''bacterial rhodopsins''' are [[Retinylidene protein|retinal-binding proteins]] that provide light-dependent [[ion transport]] and sensory functions in [[Halobacteria|halophilic]]<ref name="OesterheltTittor1989">{{cite journal|last1=Oesterhelt|first1=Dieter|last2=Tittor|first2=Jörg|title=Two pumps, one principle: light-driven ion transport in halobacteria|journal=Trends in Biochemical Sciences|volume=14|issue=2|year=1989|pages=57–61|issn=0968-0004|doi=10.1016/0968-0004(89)90044-3|pmid=2468194}}</ref> <ref name="PUB00001180">{{cite journal |vauthors=Lottspeich F, Oesterhelt D, Blanck A, Ferrando E, Schegk ES |title=Primary structure of sensory rhodopsin I, a prokaryotic photoreceptor |journal=EMBO J. |volume=8 |issue=13 |pages=3963–3971|year=1989 |pmid=2591367 |pmc=401571|doi=10.1002/j.1460-2075.1989.tb08579.x }}</ref> and other bacteria. They are integral membrane proteins with seven transmembrane helices, the last of which contains the attachment point for [[retinal]] (a conserved lysine).
This protein family includes light-driven [[proton pumps]], [[ion pumps]] and [[ion channels]], as well as light sensors. For example, the proteins from [[halobacteria]] include [[bacteriorhodopsin]] and [[archaerhodopsin]], which are light-driven [[proton pump]]s; [[halorhodopsin]], a light-driven chloride pump; and sensory rhodopsin, which mediates both [[Phototropism|photoattractant]] (in the red) and [[photophobic]] (in the ultra-violet) responses. Proteins from other bacteria include [[proteorhodopsin]].
Contrary to their name, microbial rhodopsins are found not only in [[Archaea]] and [[Bacteria]], but also in [[Eukaryota]] (such as [[algae]]) and [[viruses]]; although they are rare in complex [[multicellular organism]]s.<ref name="BoeufAudic2015">{{cite journal|last1=Boeuf|first1=Dominique|last2=Audic|first2=Stéphane|last3=Brillet-Guéguen|first3=Loraine|last4=Caron|first4=Christophe|last5=Jeanthon|first5=Christian|title=MicRhoDE: a curated database for the analysis of microbial rhodopsin diversity and evolution|journal=Database|volume=2015|year=2015|pages=bav080|url=http://database.oxfordjournals.org/content/2015/bav080.full|issn=1758-0463|doi=10.1093/database/bav080|pmid=26286928|pmc=4539915}}</ref><ref name="YawoKandori2015">{{cite book|last1=Yawo|first1=Hiromu|last2=Kandori|first2=Hideki|last3=Koizumi|first3=Amane|title=Optogenetics: Light-Sensing Proteins and Their Applications|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5M3WCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA3|accessdate=30 September 2015|date=5 June 2015|publisher=Springer|isbn=978-4-431-55516-2|pages=3–4}}</ref>
== Nomenclature == '''Rhodopsin''' was originally a synonym for "[[Rhodopsin|visual purple]]", a visual [[Biological pigment|pigment]] (light-sensitive molecule) found in the [[retina]]s of frogs and other [[vertebrate]]s, used for [[Scotopic vision|dim-light vision]], and usually found in [[rod cells]]. This is still the meaning of rhodopsin in the narrow sense, any protein evolutionarily [[Homology (biology)|homologous]] to this protein. In a broad non-genetic sense, rhodopsin refers to any molecule, whether related by genetic descent or not (mostly not), consisting of an opsin and a chromophore (generally a variant of retinal). All animal rhodopsins arose (by gene duplication and divergence) late in the history of the large [[G-protein coupled receptor]] (GPCR) gene family, which itself arose after the divergence of plants, fungi, choanflagellates and sponges from the earliest animals. The retinal chromophore is found solely in the opsin branch of this large gene family, meaning its occurrence elsewhere represents convergent evolution, not homology. Microbial rhodopsins are, by sequence, very different from any of the GPCR families.<ref name=pmid21402729>{{cite journal |vauthors= Nordström KJ, Sällman Almén M, Edstam MM, Fredriksson R, Schiöth HB |title= Independent HHsearch, Needleman—Wunsch-based, and motif analyses reveal the overall hierarchy for most of the G protein-coupled receptor families |journal= Molecular Biology and Evolution |volume= 28 |issue= 9 |pages= 2471–80 |date= September 2011 |pmid= 21402729 |doi= 10.1093/molbev/msr061}}</ref>
The term '''bacterial rhodopsin''' originally referred to the first microbial rhodopsin discovered, known today as [[bacteriorhodopsin]]. The first bacteriorhodopsin turned out to be of archaeal origin, from ''[[Halobacterium salinarum]]''.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grote|first=Mathias|last2=O'Malley|first2=Maureen A.|date=2011-11-01|title=Enlightening the life sciences: the history of halobacterial and microbial rhodopsin research|journal=FEMS Microbiology Reviews|volume=35|issue=6|pages=1082–1099|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6976.2011.00281.x|issn=1574-6976|pmid=21623844}}</ref> Since then, other microbial rhodopsins have been discovered, rendering the term ''bacterial rhodopsin'' ambiguous.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |date=19 December 2012 |title =rhodopsin, n. |encyclopedia=OED Online |publisher=Oxford University Press |location= |id=|url=http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/165304 }}</ref><ref name="PhD2011">{{cite book|last=Mason|first=Peggy|title=Medical Neurobiology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IcRqgPnstUUC&pg=PA375|accessdate=21 September 2015|date=26 May 2011|publisher=OUP USA|isbn=978-0-19-533997-0|page=375}}</ref>

==The Ion-Translocating Microbial Rhodopsin Family== The '''Ion-translocating Microbial Rhodopsin (MR) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.E.1 TC# 3.E.1]) is a member of the [[TOG Superfamily]] of secondary carriers. Members of the MR family [[Catalysis|catalyze]] light-driven ion translocation across microbial cytoplasmic membranes or serve as light receptors. Most proteins of the MR family are all of about the same size (250-350 amino acyl residues) and possess seven [[Transmembrane domain|transmembrane]] helical spanners with their [[N-terminus|N-termini]] on the outside and their [[C-terminus|C-termini]] on the inside. There are 9 subfamilies in the MR family:<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url = http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.E.1#ref9955|title = 3.E.1 The Ion-translocating Microbial Rhodopsin (MR) Family|date = |access-date = |website = Transporter Classification Database|publisher = Saier Lab Bioinformatics Group / SDSC|last = Saier|first = MH Jr.}}</ref>

===Function=== The association of sensory rhodopsins with their transducer proteins appears to determine whether they function as transporters or receptors. Association of a sensory rhodopsin receptor with its transducer occurs via the transmembrane helical domains of the two interacting proteins. There are two sensory rhodopsins in any one halophilic archaeon, one (SRI) that responds positively to orange light but negatively to blue light, the other (SRII) that responds only negatively to blue light. Each transducer is specific for its cognate receptor. An x-ray structure of SRII complexed with its transducer (HtrII) at 1.94 Å resolution is available ({{PDB2|1H2S}}).<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Molecular basis of transmembrane signalling by sensory rhodopsin II-transducer complex|journal = Nature|date = 2002-10-03|issn = 0028-0836|pmid = 12368857|pages = 484–487|volume = 419|issue = 6906|doi = 10.1038/nature01109|first = Valentin I.|last = Gordeliy|first2 = Jörg|last2 = Labahn|first3 = Rouslan|last3 = Moukhametzianov|first4 = Rouslan|last4 = Efremov|first5 = Joachim|last5 = Granzin|first6 = Ramona|last6 = Schlesinger|first7 = Georg|last7 = Büldt|first8 = Tudor|last8 = Savopol|first9 = Axel J.|last9 = Scheidig}}</ref> Molecular and evolutionary aspects of the light-signal transduction by microbial sensory receptors have been reviewed.<ref name="Inoue 562–577">{{Cite journal|title = Molecular and evolutionary aspects of microbial sensory rhodopsins|journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|date = 2014-05-01|issn = 0006-3002|pmid = 23732219|pages = 562–577|volume = 1837|issue = 5|doi = 10.1016/j.bbabio.2013.05.005|first = Keiichi|last = Inoue|first2 = Takashi|last2 = Tsukamoto|first3 = Yuki|last3 = Sudo}}</ref>

===Bacteriorhodopsins and Halorhodopsins===
Bacterio- and halorhodopsins pump 1 H<sup>+</sup> and 1 Cl<sup>−</sup> per photon absorbed, respectively. Specific transport mechanisms and pathways have been proposed.<ref name="Kolbe 1390–1396"/><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|title = Mechanism of proton transport in bacteriorhodopsin from crystallographic structures of the K, L, M1, M2, and M2' intermediates of the photocycle|journal = Journal of Molecular Biology|date = 2003-04-25|issn = 0022-2836|pmid = 12691752|pages = 439–450|volume = 328|issue = 2|first = Janos K.|last = Lanyi|first2 = Brigitte|last2 = Schobert|doi=10.1016/s0022-2836(03)00263-8}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title = Crystallographic structures of the M and N intermediates of bacteriorhodopsin: assembly of a hydrogen-bonded chain of water molecules between Asp-96 and the retinal Schiff base|journal = Journal of Molecular Biology|date = 2003-07-11|issn = 0022-2836|pmid = 12842471|pages = 553–570|volume = 330|issue = 3|first = Brigitte|last = Schobert|first2 = Leonid S.|last2 = Brown|first3 = Janos K.|last3 = Lanyi|doi=10.1016/s0022-2836(03)00576-x}}</ref> The mechanism involves:
# photo-isomerization of the retinal and its initial configurational changes, # deprotonation of the retinal Schiff base and the coupled release of a proton to the extracellular membrane surface, # the switch event that allows reprotonation of the Schiff base from the cytoplasmic side.
Six structural models describe the transformations of the retinal and its interaction with water 402, Asp85, and Asp212 in atomic detail, as well as the displacements of functional residues farther from the [[Schiff base]]. The changes provide rationales for how relaxation of the distorted retinal causes movements of water and protein atoms that result in vectorial proton transfers to and from the Schiff base.<ref name=":4" /> Helix deformation is coupled to vectorial proton transport in the photocycle of bacteriorhodopsin.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Helix deformation is coupled to vectorial proton transport in the photocycle of bacteriorhodopsin|journal = Nature|date = 2000-08-10|issn = 0028-0836|pmid = 10949307|pages = 645–648|volume = 406|issue = 6796|doi = 10.1038/35020599|first = A.|last = Royant|first2 = K.|last2 = Edman|first3 = T.|last3 = Ursby|first4 = E.|last4 = Pebay-Peyroula|first5 = E. M.|last5 = Landau|first6 = R.|last6 = Neutze}}</ref>
Most residues participating in the trimerization are not conserved in bacteriorhodopsin, a homologous protein capable of forming a trimeric structure in the absence of bacterioruberin. Despite a large alteration in the amino acid sequence, the shape of the intratrimer hydrophobic space filled by lipids is highly conserved between archaerhodopsin-2 and bacteriorhodopsin. Since a transmembrane helix facing this space undergoes a large conformational change during the proton pumping cycle, it is feasible that trimerization is an important strategy to capture special lipid components that are relevant to the protein activity.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|title = Structural role of bacterioruberin in the trimeric structure of archaerhodopsin-2|journal = Journal of Molecular Biology|date = 2008-02-01|issn = 1089-8638|pmid = 18082767|pages = 1267–1281|volume = 375|issue = 5|doi = 10.1016/j.jmb.2007.11.039|first = Keiko|last = Yoshimura|first2 = Tsutomu|last2 = Kouyama}}</ref>
===Marine Bacterial Rhodopsin===
A marine bacterial rhodopsin has been reported to function as a proton pump. However, it also resembles sensory rhodopsin II of archaea as well as an Orf from the fungus ''Leptosphaeria maculans'' (AF290180). These proteins exhibit 20-30% identity with each other.
===Channelrhodopsins===
[[Channelrhodopsin]]-1 (ChR1) or channelopsin-1 (Chop1; Cop3; CSOA) of ''C. reinhardtii'' is closely related to the archaeal sensory rhodopsins. It has 712 aas with a signal peptide, followed by a short amphipathic region, and then a hydrophobic N-terminal domain with seven probable TMSs (residues 76-309) followed by a long hydrophilic C-terminal domain of about 400 residues. Part of the C-terminal hydrophilic domain is homologous to intersectin (EH and SH3 domain protein 1A) of animals (AAD30271).
Chop1 serves as a light-gated proton channel and mediates phototaxis and photophobic responses in green algae.<ref name=":3" /> Based on this phenotype, Chop1 could be assigned to [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=1.A TC category #1.A], but because it belongs to a family in which well-characterized homologues catalyze active ion transport, it is assigned to the MR family. Expression of the ''chop1'' gene, or a truncated form of that gene encoding only the hydrophobic core (residues 1-346 or 1-517) in frog oocytes in the presence of all-trans retinal produces a light-gated conductance that shows characteristics of a channel passively but selectively permeable to protons. This channel activity probably generates bioelectric currents.<ref name=":3" />
A homologue of ChR1 in ''C. reinhardtii'' is channelrhodopsin-2 (ChR2; Chop2; Cop4; CSOB). This protein is 57% identical, 10% similar to ChR1. It forms a cation-selective ion channel activated by light absorption. It transports both monovalent and divalent cations. It desensitizes to a small conductance in continuous light. Recovery from desensitization is accelerated by extracellular H<sup>+</sup> and a negative membrane potential. It may be a photoreceptor for dark adapted cells.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Channelrhodopsin-2, a directly light-gated cation-selective membrane channel|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date = 2003-11-25|issn = 0027-8424|pmc = 283525|pmid = 14615590|pages = 13940–13945|volume = 100|issue = 24|doi = 10.1073/pnas.1936192100|first = Georg|last = Nagel|first2 = Tanjef|last2 = Szellas|first3 = Wolfram|last3 = Huhn|first4 = Suneel|last4 = Kateriya|first5 = Nona|last5 = Adeishvili|first6 = Peter|last6 = Berthold|first7 = Doris|last7 = Ollig|first8 = Peter|last8 = Hegemann|first9 = Ernst|last9 = Bamberg}}</ref> A transient increase in hydration of transmembrane α-helices with a t(1/2) = 60 μs tallies with the onset of cation permeation. Aspartate 253 accepts the proton released by the Schiff base (t(1/2) = 10 μs), with the latter being reprotonated by aspartic acid 156 (t(1/2) = 2 ms). The internal proton acceptor and donor groups, corresponding to D212 and D115 in bacteriorhodopsin, are clearly different from other microbial rhodopsins, indicating that their spatial positions in the protein were relocated during evolution. E90 deprotonates exclusively in the nonconductive state. The observed proton transfer reactions and the protein conformational changes relate to the gating of the cation channel.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Transient protonation changes in channelrhodopsin-2 and their relevance to channel gating|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|date = 2013-04-02|issn = 1091-6490|pmc = 3619329|pmid = 23509282|pages = E1273–1281|volume = 110|issue = 14|doi = 10.1073/pnas.1219502110|first = Víctor A.|last = Lórenz-Fonfría|first2 = Tom|last2 = Resler|first3 = Nils|last3 = Krause|first4 = Melanie|last4 = Nack|first5 = Michael|last5 = Gossing|first6 = Gabriele|last6 = Fischer von Mollard|first7 = Christian|last7 = Bamann|first8 = Ernst|last8 = Bamberg|first9 = Ramona|last9 = Schlesinger}}</ref>
===Archaerhodopsin===
Archaerhodopsin-2 (aR2) was found in the claret membrane of ''Halorubrum sp''. It is a light-driven proton pump. Trigonal and hexagonal crystals revealed that trimers are arranged on a honeycomb lattice.<ref name=":5" /> In these crystals, the carotenoid bacterioruberin binds to crevices between the subunits of the trimer. Its polyene chain is inclined from the membrane normal by an angle of about 20 degrees and, on the cytoplasmic side, it is surrounded by helices AB and DE of neighboring subunits. This peculiar binding mode suggests that bacterioruberin plays a structural role for the trimerization of aR2. When compared with the aR2 structure in another crystal form containing no bacterioruberin, the proton release channel takes a more closed conformation in the P321 or P6(3) crystal; i.e., the native conformation of protein is stabilized in the trimeric protein-bacterioruberin complex.
==Transport Reaction== The generalized transport reaction for bacterio- and sensory rhodopsins is:<ref name=":6" />
:H<sup>+</sup> (in) + hν → H<sup>+</sup> (out).
That for halorhodopsin is:
:Cl<sup>−</sup> (out) + hν → Cl<sup>−</sup> (in).

revision.comment: replace link to deleted [[Portal:Molecular and cellular biology]] (+aliases) with [[Portal:Biology]]
revision.text:
{{Pfam_box | Symbol = PnuC | Name = | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam = PF04973 | Pfam_clan = | InterPro = | SMART = | PROSITE = | SCOP = | TCDB = 4.B.1 | OPM family = 377 | OPM protein = 4qtn | PDB = }} The '''Nicotinamide Ribonucleoside (NR) Uptake Permease (PnuC) Family''' ([http://tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=4.B.1 TC# 4.B.1]) is a family of transmembrane transporters that is part of the [[TOG superfamily]].<ref name="Yee_2013">{{cite journal | vauthors = Yee DC, Shlykov MA, Västermark A, Reddy VS, Arora S, Sun EI, Saier MH | title = The transporter-opsin-G protein-coupled receptor (TOG) superfamily | journal = The FEBS Journal | volume = 280 | issue = 22 | pages = 5780–800 | date = November 2013 | pmid = 23981446 | pmc = 3832197 | doi = 10.1111/febs.12499 }}</ref> Close PnuC homologues are found in a wide range of [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria]], [[archaea]] and [[eukaryote]]s.<ref name="TCB">{{cite web|url = http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=4.B.1#ref3139|title = 4.B.1 The Nicotinamide Ribonucleoside (NR) Uptake Permease (PnuC) Family|date = |access-date = |website = Transporter Classification Database|publisher = Saier Lab Bioinformatics Group / SDSC|last = Saier|first = MH Jr.}}</ref>
== Function == PnuC of ''[[Salmonella typhimurium]]'' and ''[[Haemophilus influenzae]]'' are believed to function cooperatively with NadR homologues, multifunctional proteins that together with PnuC, participate in NR [[phosphorylation]], transport and [[transcriptional regulation]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Foster JW, Park YK, Penfound T, Fenger T, Spector MP | title = Regulation of NAD metabolism in Salmonella typhimurium: molecular sequence analysis of the bifunctional nadR regulator and the nadA-pnuC operon | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 172 | issue = 8 | pages = 4187–96 | date = August 1990 | pmid = 2198247 | pmc = 213241 }}</ref><ref name="Merdanovic_2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Merdanovic M, Sauer E, Reidl J | title = Coupling of NAD+ biosynthesis and nicotinamide ribosyl transport: characterization of NadR ribonucleotide kinase mutants of Haemophilus influenzae | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 187 | issue = 13 | pages = 4410–20 | date = July 2005 | pmid = 15968050 | pmc = 1151767 | doi = 10.1128/JB.187.13.4410-4420.2005 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Penfound T, Foster JW | title = NAD-dependent DNA-binding activity of the bifunctional NadR regulator of Salmonella typhimurium | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 181 | issue = 2 | pages = 648–55 | date = January 1999 | pmid = 9882682 | pmc = 93422 }}</ref> NadR, a cytoplasmic protein that is partly membrane associated, contains one well conserved and one poorly conserved mononucleotide-binding [[consensus sequence]] (G-X4 GKS). It drives transport and may render transport responsive to internal pyridine nucleotide levels. While its N-terminal half functions as a repressor, its C-terminal half functions as an NR kinase in a putative group translocation process.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mitchell P, Moyle J | title = Group-translocation: a consequence of enzyme-catalysed group-transfer | journal = Nature | volume = 182 | issue = 4632 | pages = 372–3 | date = August 1958 | pmid = 13577842 | doi = 10.1038/182372a0 }}</ref>
===PnuC of ''Haemophilus influenzae''=== The ''H. influenzae'' homologue has been shown to transport NR from the periplasm into the cytoplasm. Phosphorylation of NR by NadR is required for NR uptake. The ribonucleoside [[kinase]] (RNK) domain has both [[Walker A motif|Walker A]] and [[Walker motifs|Walker B motifs]], responsible for ATP binding and phosphoryl transfer. In addition, a proposed LID domain was identified in RNK. LID domains have been found in other kinases, and these domains are regions which are able to move after substrate binding. They are responsible for coordination of three distinct conformations, an open state in the absence of substrate, a partially closed state after substrate binding, and a fully closed state when both substrates are present.
In ''H. influenzae'', NR enters the [[Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide|NAD<sup>+</sup>]] resynthesis pathway after [[phosphorylation]] to NMN, and subsequently, NAD<sup>+</sup> is synthesized from NMN and ATP via an NMN adenylyl transferase activity.<ref name="Kurnasov 6906–6917"/><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cynamon MH, Sorg TB, Patapow A | title = Utilization and metabolism of NAD by Haemophilus parainfluenzae | journal = Journal of General Microbiology | volume = 134 | issue = 10 | pages = 2789–99 | date = October 1988 | pmid = 3254936 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-134-10-2789 }}</ref> NadR represents a multifunctional regulator/enzyme complex able to integrate several functions, such as enzymatic catalysis, transport, and transcriptional regulatory activities.
==Other constituents required for uptake== The components of the ''H. influenzae'' pathway necessary for NAD<sup>+</sup>, NMN, and NR uptake have been determined. Merdanovic et al. characterized two enzymes, an outer membrane nucleotide phosphatase, and an NAD<sup>+</sup> nucleotidase (NadN) located in the periplasm.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kemmer G, Reilly TJ, Schmidt-Brauns J, Zlotnik GW, Green BA, Fiske MJ, Herbert M, Kraiss A, Schlör S, Smith A, Reidl J | title = NadN and e (P4) are essential for utilization of NAD and nicotinamide mononucleotide but not nicotinamide riboside in Haemophilus influenzae | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 183 | issue = 13 | pages = 3974–81 | date = July 2001 | pmid = 11395461 | pmc = 95280 | doi = 10.1128/JB.183.13.3974-3981.2001 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Reidl J, Schlör S, Kraiss A, Schmidt-Brauns J, Kemmer G, Soleva E | title = NADP and NAD utilization in Haemophilus influenzae | journal = Molecular Microbiology | volume = 35 | issue = 6 | pages = 1573–81 | date = March 2000 | pmid = 10760156 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-2958.2000.01829.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Schmidt-Brauns J, Herbert M, Kemmer G, Kraiss A, Schlör S, Reidl J | title = Is a NAD pyrophosphatase activity necessary for Haemophilus influenzae type b multiplication in the blood stream? | journal = International Journal of Medical Microbiology | volume = 291 | issue = 3 | pages = 219–25 | date = August 2001 | pmid = 11554562 | doi = 10.1078/1438-4221-00122 }}</ref> They showed that NAD<sup>+</sup> and NMN cross the outer membrane mainly via the OmpP2 porin.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Andersen C, Maier E, Kemmer G, Blass J, Hilpert AK, Benz R, Reidl J | title = Porin OmpP2 of Haemophilus influenzae shows specificity for nicotinamide-derived nucleotide substrates | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 278 | issue = 27 | pages = 24269–76 | date = July 2003 | pmid = 12695515 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M213087200 }}</ref>
Only NR can be utilized by the PnuC transport system located in the inner membrane.<ref name="Herbert_2003">{{cite journal | vauthors = Herbert M, Sauer E, Smethurst G, Kraiss A, Hilpert AK, Reidl J | title = Nicotinamide ribosyl uptake mutants in Haemophilus influenzae | journal = Infection and Immunity | volume = 71 | issue = 9 | pages = 5398–401 | date = September 2003 | pmid = 12933892 | pmc = 187334 | doi = 10.1128/iai.71.9.5398-5401.2003 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Sauer E, Merdanovic M, Mortimer AP, Bringmann G, Reidl J | title = PnuC and the utilization of the nicotinamide riboside analog 3-aminopyridine in Haemophilus influenzae | journal = Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy | volume = 48 | issue = 12 | pages = 4532–41 | date = December 2004 | pmid = 15561822 | pmc = 529221 | doi = 10.1128/AAC.48.12.4532-4541.2004 }}</ref> The ''pnuC'' gene product is the protein that is responsible for the main flow of the NR substrate into the cytoplasm. The study of Merdanovic et al. suggests that the RNK activity of NadR determines NR transport and is negatively regulated by cytoplasmic NAD<sup>+</sup> feedback inhibition. Therefore, NR uptake is under NadR feedback control.<ref name="Merdanovic_2005" />
ATP, not the [[proton motive force]], appears to be required for NR uptake. Thus, the driving force for NR uptake via PnuC is NR phosphorylation by NadR. A concerted group translocation mechanism can be considered whereby NadR facilitates the dissociation of NR from PnuC by phosphorylating it to NMN, thus preventing efflux of NR.
===Transport reaction=== The proposed transport reaction catalyzed by PnuC and NadR is:<ref name="TCB" />
NR (out) + ATP (in) → NMN (in) + ADP (in).
== Structure == PnuC of ''[[Salmonella enterica subsp. enterica|Salmonella typhimurium]]'' and ''[[Haemophilus influenzae]]'' are [[integral membrane protein]]s, 239 and 226 amino acyl residues (aas) in length, respectively, with 7 putative [[Transmembrane domain|transmembrane]] [[Alpha helix|α-helical segments]].
The structure of NadR has been determined.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Singh SK, Kurnasov OV, Chen B, Robinson H, Grishin NV, Osterman AL, Zhang H | title = Crystal structure of Haemophilus influenzae NadR protein. A bifunctional enzyme endowed with NMN adenyltransferase and ribosylnicotinimide kinase activities | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 277 | issue = 36 | pages = 33291–9 | date = September 2002 | pmid = 12068016 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M204368200 }}</ref> Mutations in the ''nadR'' gene which interfere with NR uptake occur in the [[C-terminus|C-terminal]] part of NadR.<ref name="Foster_1993">{{cite journal | vauthors = Foster JW, Penfound T | title = The bifunctional NadR regulator of Salmonella typhimurium: location of regions involved with DNA binding, nucleotide transport and intramolecular communication | journal = FEMS Microbiology Letters | volume = 112 | issue = 2 | pages = 179–83 | date = September 1993 | pmid = 8405960 | doi = 10.1016/0378-1097(93)90161-t }}</ref> A [[helix-turn-helix]] DNA binding domain present in NadR of ''S. enterica serovar Typhimurium'' <ref name="Foster_1993" /> could not be found in the NadR homologue of ''H. influenzae''. Therefore, it was proposed that in ''H. influenzae'' NadR has no regulatory function at the transcriptional level.<ref name="Kurnasov 6906–6917">{{cite journal | vauthors = Kurnasov OV, Polanuyer BM, Ananta S, Sloutsky R, Tam A, Gerdes SY, Osterman AL | title = Ribosylnicotinamide kinase domain of NadR protein: identification and implications in NAD biosynthesis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 184 | issue = 24 | pages = 6906–17 | date = December 2002 | pmid = 12446641 | pmc = 135457 | doi = 10.1128/jb.184.24.6906-6917.2002 }}</ref> The structures of the human NR kinase 1 (2QL6_P) with nucleotide and nucleoside substrates bound have been solved.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Tempel W, Rabeh WM, Bogan KL, Belenky P, Wojcik M, Seidle HF, Nedyalkova L, Yang T, Sauve AA, Park HW, Brenner C | title = Nicotinamide riboside kinase structures reveal new pathways to NAD+ | journal = PLoS Biology | volume = 5 | issue = 10 | pages = e263 | date = October 2007 | pmid = 17914902 | pmc = 1994991 | doi = 10.1371/journal.pbio.0050263 }}</ref> It is structurally similar to [[Rossmann fold]] metabolite kinases.
PnuC has been shown to resemble SWEET porters in overall fold,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Jaehme M, Guskov A, Slotboom DJ | title = Pnu Transporters: Ain't They SWEET? | journal = Trends in Biochemical Sciences | volume = 41 | issue = 2 | pages = 117–118 | date = February 2016 | pmid = 26692123 | doi = 10.1016/j.tibs.2015.11.013 }}</ref> supporting the conclusion that these two families are members of the TOG superfamily.<ref name="Yee_2013" />

NR transporter PnuC {{PDB|4QTN}}

revision.text:
{{Pfam_box|Symbol=|Name=|image=|width=|caption=|Pfam=PF01566|InterPro=|SMART=|Prosite=|SCOP=|TCDB=2.A.55|OPM family=64|OPM protein=4wgv|PDB=}} '''Natural resistance-associated macrophage proteins''' (NRAMPs) are members of the '''metal ion (Mn<sup>2+</sup>-iron) transporter family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.55 TC# 2.A.55]). The NRAMP family is a member of the large [[APC Superfamily]] of secondary carriers.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Vastermark A, Wollwage S, Houle ME, Rio R, Saier MH | title = Expansion of the APC superfamily of secondary carriers | journal = Proteins | volume = 82 | issue = 10 | pages = 2797–811 | date = October 2014 | pmid = 25043943 | pmc = 4177346 | doi = 10.1002/prot.24643 }}</ref> Homologues of this family are found in various [[yeast]]s, [[plant]]s, [[animal]]s, [[archaea]], and [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria]] termed "natural resistance-associated" [[macrophage]] proteins because one of the animal homologues plays a role in resistance to intracellular bacterial [[pathogen]]s such as ''[https://microbewiki.kenyon.edu/index.php/Salmonella_enterica_serovar_Typhi Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium]'', ''[[Leishmania donovani]]'' and ''[[Mycobacterium bovis]]''. The natural history of ''SLC11'' genes in vertebrates has been discussed by Neves et al. (2011).<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Neves JV, Wilson JM, Kuhl H, Reinhardt R, Castro LF, Rodrigues PN | title = Natural history of SLC11 genes in vertebrates: tales from the fish world | journal = BMC Evolutionary Biology | volume = 11 | pages = 106 | date = April 2011 | pmid = 21501491 | pmc = 3103463 | doi = 10.1186/1471-2148-11-106 }}</ref> Proposed to be a distant member of the [[APC Superfamily]], several human pathologies may result from defects in NRAMP-dependent Fe<sup>2+</sup> or Mn<sup>2+</sup> transport, including iron overload, neurodegenerative diseases and innate susceptibility to infectious diseases.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cellier MF | title = Nramp: from sequence to structure and mechanism of divalent metal import | journal = Current Topics in Membranes | volume = 69 | pages = 249–93 | date = 2012-01-01 | pmid = 23046654 | doi = 10.1016/B978-0-12-394390-3.00010-0 }}</ref>
==NRAMP2== {{Main|DMT1}} Humans and rodents possess two distinct NRAMPs. The broad specificity NRAMP2 (DMT1), which transports a range of divalent metal cations, transports Fe<sup>2+</sup> and H<sup>+</sup> with a 1:1 stoichiometry and apparent affinities of 6 μm and about 1 μm, respectively. Variable H<sup>+</sup>:Fe<sup>2+</sup> stoichiometry has also been reported. The order of substrate preference for NRAMP2 is:
Fe<sup>2+</sup>> Zn<sup>2+</sup>> Mn<sup>2+</sup>> Co<sup>2+</sup>> Ca<sup>2+</sup>> Cu<sup>2+</sup>> Ni<sup>2+</sup>> Pb<sup>2+</sup>
Many of these ions can inhibit iron absorption. Mutation of NRAMP2 in rodents leads to defective [[Endosome|endosomal]] iron export within the ferritin cycle, impaired intestinal iron absorption and [[microcytic anemia]]. Symptoms of Mn<sup>2+</sup> deficiency are also seen. It is found in apical membranes of intestinal epithelial cells but also in late [[endosome]]s and [[lysosome]]s.
==NRAMP1== {{Main|SLC11A1}} In contrast to the widely expressed NRAMP2, NRAMP1 is expressed primarily in [[macrophage]]s and [[monocyte]]s and appears to have a preference for Mn<sup>2+</sup> rather than Fe<sup>2+</sup>. NRAMP1 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.55.2.3 TC# 2.A.55.2.3]) has been reported to function by metal:H<sup>+</sup> antiport.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Techau ME, Valdez-Taubas J, Popoff JF, Francis R, Seaman M, Blackwell JM | title = Evolution of differences in transport function in Slc11a family members | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 282 | issue = 49 | pages = 35646–56 | date = December 2007 | pmid = 17932044 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M707057200 }}</ref> It is hypothesized that a deficiency for Mn<sup>2+</sup> or some other metal prevents the generation of reactive oxygenic and nitrogenic compounds that are used by macrophage to combat pathogens. This hypothesis is supported by studies on the bacterial NRAMP homologues which exhibit extremely high selectivity for Mn<sup>2+</sup> over Fe<sup>2+</sup>, Zn<sup>2+</sup> and other divalent cations.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wei W, Chai T, Zhang Y, Han L, Xu J, Guan Z | title = The Thlaspi caerulescens NRAMP homologue TcNRAMP3 is capable of divalent cation transport | journal = Molecular Biotechnology | volume = 41 | issue = 1 | pages = 15–21 | date = January 2009 | pmid = 18663607 | doi = 10.1007/s12033-008-9088-x }}</ref> Regulation of these transporters in bacteria can occur through Fur, OxyR, and most commonly a DtxR homolog, MntR.
==Smf and other homologues== The Smf1 protein of ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' appears to catalyze high-affinity (''K<sub>M</sub>'' = 0.3 μm) Mn<sup>2+</sup> uptake while the closely related Smf2 protein may catalyze low affinity (''K<sub>M</sub>'' = 60 μm) Mn<sup>2+</sup> uptake in the same organism. Both proteins also mediate H<sup>+</sup>-dependent Fe<sup>2+</sup> uptake. These proteins are of 575 and 549 amino acyl residues in length and are predicted to have 8-12 transmembrane α-helical spanners. The ''E. coli'' homologue of 412 aas exhibits 11 putative and confirmed TMSs with the N-terminus in and the C-terminus out. The yeast proteins may be localized to the vacuole and/or the plasma membrane of the yeast cell. Indirect and some direct experiments suggest that they may be able to transport several heavy metals including Mn<sup>2+</sup>, Cu<sup>2+</sup>, Cd<sup>2+</sup> and Co<sup>2+</sup>. A third yeast protein, Smf3p, appears to be exclusively intracellular, possibly in the Golgi. NRAMP2 (''[[SLC11A2|Slc11A2]]'') of Homo sapiens ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.55.2.1 TC# 2.A.55.2.1]) has a 12 TMS topology with intracellular N- and C-termini. Two-fold structural symmetry in the arrangement of membrane helices for TM1-5 and TM6-10 (conserved Slc2 hydrophobic core) is suggested.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Czachorowski M, Lam-Yuk-Tseung S, Cellier M, Gros P | title = Transmembrane topology of the mammalian Slc11a2 iron transporter | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 48 | issue = 35 | pages = 8422–34 | date = September 2009 | pmid = 19621945 | pmc = 2736113 | doi = 10.1021/bi900606y }}</ref>
==Transport reaction== The generalized transport reaction catalyzed by NRAMP family proteins is:
Me<sup>2+</sup> (out) + H<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Me<sup>2+</sup> (in) + H<sup>+</sup> (in).
