{{DISPLAYTITLE:''p''-Aminobenzoyl-glutamate transporter}} {{Pfam_box | Symbol = AbgT | Name = | image = | width = | caption = | Pfam = PF03806 | Pfam_clan = | InterPro = | SMART = | PROSITE = | SCOP = | TCDB = 2.A.68 | OPM family = 272 | OPM protein = 4r1i | PDB = }} The '''''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate transporter''' '''(AbgT) family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.68 TC# 2.A.68]) is a family of transporter proteins belonging to the [[Ion transporter|ion transporter (IT) superfamily]].{{cite journal | vauthors = Prakash S, Cooper G, Singhi S, Saier MH | title = The ion transporter superfamily | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1618 | issue = 1 | pages = 79–92 | date = December 2003 | pmid = 14643936 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010 }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Rabus R, Jack DL, Kelly DJ, Saier MH | title = TRAP transporters: an ancient family of extracytoplasmic solute-receptor-dependent secondary active transporters | journal = Microbiology | volume = 145 ( Pt 12) | issue = 12 | pages = 3431–45 | date = December 1999 | pmid = 10627041 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-145-12-3431 }} The AbgT family consists of the AbgT (YdaH; [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.68.1.1 TC# 2.A.68.1.1]) protein of ''E. coli'' and the MtrF drug exporter ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.68.1.2 TC# 2.A.68.1.2]) of ''[[Neisseria gonorrhoeae]]''.{{cite journal | vauthors = Hussein MJ, Green JM, Nichols BP | title = Characterization of mutations that allow p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate utilization by Escherichia coli | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 180 | issue = 23 | pages = 6260–8 | date = December 1998 | pmid = 9829935 | pmc = 107711 }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Folster JP, Shafer WM | title = Regulation of mtrF expression in Neisseria gonorrhoeae and its role in high-level antimicrobial resistance | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 187 | issue = 11 | pages = 3713–20 | date = June 2005 | pmid = 15901695 | pmc = 1112036 | doi = 10.1128/JB.187.11.3713-3720.2005 }} The former protein is apparently cryptic in wild-type cells, but when expressed on a high copy number plasmid, or when expressed at higher levels due to mutation, it appeared to allow uptake (''K''m = 123 nM; see [[Michaelis–Menten kinetics]]) and subsequent utilization of ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate as a source of [[P aminobenzoate|''p''-aminobenzoate]] for ''p''-aminobenzoate [[Auxotrophy|auxotrophs]].{{cite journal | vauthors = Carter EL, Jager L, Gardner L, Hall CC, Willis S, Green JM | title = Escherichia coli abg genes enable uptake and cleavage of the folate catabolite p-aminobenzoyl-glutamate | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 189 | issue = 9 | pages = 3329–34 | date = May 2007 | pmid = 17307853 | pmc = 1855889 | doi = 10.1128/JB.01940-06 }} ''p''-Aminobenzoate is a constituent of and a precursor for the biosynthesis of [[folic acid]]. MtrF was annotated as a putative [[Efflux (microbiology)|drug efflux pump]]. == Structure == AbgT is 510 amino acyl residues long and has 12-13 putative transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs). MtrF is 522 aas long and has 11 or 12 putative TMSs. The 3-d structures of MtrF and a YdaH homologue have been solved, and functional studies show that it is a drug exporter. The 3-d structure shows that it has 9 TMSs with hairpin entry loops.{{cite journal | vauthors = Su CC, Bolla JR, Kumar N, Radhakrishnan A, Long F, Delmar JA, Chou TH, Rajashankar KR, Shafer WM, Yu EW | title = Structure and function of Neisseria gonorrhoeae MtrF illuminates a class of antimetabolite efflux pumps | journal = Cell Reports | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 61–70 | date = April 2015 | pmid = 25818299 | pmc = 4410016 | doi = 10.1016/j.celrep.2015.03.003 }} Crystal Structures: == Genetics == The ''abgT'' gene is preceded by two genes, ''abgA'' and ''abgB,'' which code for homologous amino acyl amino hydrolases and hydrolyze ''p''-aminobenzoyl glutamate to ''p''-aminobenzoate and glutamate. Because of the structural similarity of ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutatmate to peptides, and the enzymatic activities of the ''abgA'' and ''abgB'' gene products, it has been suggested that AbgT is also a peptide transporter. Demonstration of an energy requirement suggested an H+-dependent mechanism. Expression of these genes is regulated by AbgR and an unknown effector. == Function == As noted above, the AbgT family of transporters has been thought to contribute to bacterial [[Folic acid|folate biosynthesis]] by importing the catabolite ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate for producing folate. Approximately 13,000 putative family members were identified in 2015.{{cite journal | vauthors = Delmar JA, Yu EW | title = The AbgT family: A novel class of antimetabolite transporters | journal = Protein Science | volume = 25 | issue = 2 | pages = 322–37 | date = February 2016 | pmid = 26443496 | pmc = 4815354 | doi = 10.1002/pro.2820 }} The X-ray structures of the full-length ''[[Alcanivorax borkumensis]]'' YdaH (AbgT) and ''[[Neisseria gonorrhoeae]]'' MtrF proteins. The structures revealed that these two transporters assemble as dimers with architectures distinct from all other families of transporters for which 3-d structures were available.{{cite journal | vauthors = Bolla JR, Su CC, Delmar JA, Radhakrishnan A, Kumar N, Chou TH, Long F, Rajashankar KR, Yu EW | title = Crystal structure of the Alcanivorax borkumensis YdaH transporter reveals an unusual topology | journal = Nature Communications | volume = 6 | pages = 6874 | date = April 2015 | pmid = 25892120 | pmc = 4410182 | doi = 10.1038/ncomms7874 }} Both YdaH and MtrF are bowl-shaped dimers with a solvent-filled basin extending from the cytoplasm halfway across the [[Lipid bilayer|membrane bilayer]]. The protomers of YdaH and MtrF contain nine transmembrane helices and two hairpins which suggested a plausible pathway for substrate transport. A combination of the crystal structure, genetic analyses and substrate accumulation assays indicated that both YdaH and MtrF behave as exporters, capable of removing the folate metabolite ''p''-aminobenzoic acid from bacterial cells. In fact, it was shown that both YdaH and MtrF participate as [[Antibiotics|antibiotic]] efflux pumps, mediating bacterial resistance to [[Sulfonamide (medicine)|sulfonamide antimetabolite drugs]]. Possibly, many AbgT-family transporters act as exporters, conferring resistance to [[Sulfadiazine|sulfonamides]]. === Transport reaction === The generalized transport reaction initially proposed for AbgT is:
''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate (out) + nH+ (out) → ''p''-aminobenzoyl-glutamate (in) + nH+ (in)
but the more recently proposed transport reaction is:
Sulfonamide drugs (in) + H+ (out) → Sulfonamide drugs (out) + H+ (in)

The '''Citrate-Mg<sup>2+</sup>:H<sup>+</sup> (CitM) / Citrate-Ca<sup>2+</sup>:H<sup>+</sup> (CitH) Symporter (CitMHS) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.11 TC# 2.A.11]) is a family of transport proteins belonging to the [[Ion transporter superfamily]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}}</ref> Members of this family are found in [[Gram-positive bacteria|Gram-positive]] and [[Gram-negative bacteria]], archaea and possibly eukaryotes. These proteins all probably arose by an internal [[gene duplication]] event. Lensbouer & Doyle (2010) have reviewed these systems, classifying the porters with three superfamilies, according to ion-preference:<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lensbouer|first=Joshua J.|last2=Patel|first2=Ami|last3=Sirianni|first3=Joseph P.|last4=Doyle|first4=Robert P.|date=2008-08-01|title=Functional characterization and metal ion specificity of the metal-citrate complex transporter from Streptomyces coelicolor|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=190|issue=16|pages=5616–5623|doi=10.1128/JB.00456-08|issn=1098-5530|pmc=2519374|pmid=18556792}}</ref>
1) Mg<sup>2+</sup>-preferring,
2) Ca<sup>2+</sup>-preferring, and
3) Fe<sup>2+</sup>-preferring.
A representative list of proteins belonging to the CitMHS family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.11.2 Transporter Classification Database].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.11|title=2.A.11. The Citrate-Mg2+:H+ (CitM) Citrate-Ca2+:H+ (CitH) Symporter (CitMHS) Family|website=Transporter Classification Database|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref>
== CitM and CitH == Two of the characterized members of the CitMHS family, both [[Citric acid|citrate]] uptake permeases from ''[[Bacillus subtilis]]'', are CitM ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.11.1.1 TC# 2.A.11.1.1]) and CitH ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.11.1.2 TC# 2.A.11.1.2])''.''
=== Function === CitM is believed to transport a citrate<sup>2−</sup>-Mg<sup>2+</sup>complex in [[Symporter|symport]] with one H<sup>+</sup> per Mg<sup>2+</sup>-citrate while CitH apparently transports a citrate<sup>2−</sup>-Ca<sup>2+</sup> complex in symport with protons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boorsma|first=A.|last2=van der Rest|first2=M. E.|last3=Lolkema|first3=J. S.|last4=Konings|first4=W. N.|date=1996-11-01|title=Secondary transporters for citrate and the Mg(2+)-citrate complex in Bacillus subtilis are homologous proteins|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=178|issue=21|pages=6216–6222|issn=0021-9193|pmc=178492|pmid=8892821|doi=10.1128/jb.178.21.6216-6222.1996}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Krom|first=B. P.|last2=Warner|first2=J. B.|last3=Konings|first3=W. N.|last4=Lolkema|first4=J. S.|date=2000-11-01|title=Complementary metal ion specificity of the metal-citrate transporters CitM and CitH of Bacillus subtilis|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=182|issue=22|pages=6374–6381|issn=0021-9193|pmc=94783|pmid=11053381|doi=10.1128/jb.182.22.6374-6381.2000}}</ref> The cation specificity of CitM is: [[Magnesium|Mg<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Manganese|Mn<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Barium|Ba<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Nickel|Ni<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Cobalt|Co<sup>2+</sup>]], [[Calcium in biology|Ca<sup>2+</sup>]] and [[Zinc|Zn<sup>2+</sup>]], in this preferential order. CitM is highly specific for citrate and D-isocitrate and does not transport other di- and tri-carboxylates including succinate, L-isocitrate, cis-aconitate and tricarballylate.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Li|first=H.|last2=Pajor|first2=A. M.|date=2002-01-01|title=Functional characterization of CitM, the Mg2+-citrate transporter|journal=The Journal of Membrane Biology|volume=185|issue=1|pages=9–16|doi=10.1007/s00232-001-0106-1|issn=0022-2631|pmid=11891560}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Warner|first=Jessica B.|last2=Lolkema|first2=Juke S.|date=2002-11-01|title=Growth of Bacillus subtilis on citrate and isocitrate is supported by the Mg2+-citrate transporter CitM|journal=Microbiology|volume=148|issue=Pt 11|pages=3405–3412|doi=10.1099/00221287-148-11-3405|issn=1350-0872|pmid=12427932}}</ref> For CitH, the cation specificity (in order of preference) is: Ca<sup>2+</sup>, Ba<sup>2+</sup> and [[Strontium|Sr<sup>2+</sup>]].<ref name=":0" /> The two proteins are 60% identical, contain about 400 amino acyl residues and possess twelve putative transmembrane spanners. A CitM homologue in ''[[Streptococcus mutans|S. mutans]]'' transports citrate conjugated to [[Ferrous|Fe<sup>2+</sup>]] or Mn<sup>2+</sup> but not Ca<sup>2+</sup>, Mg<sup>2+</sup> or Ni<sup>2+</sup>.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Korithoski|first=Bryan|last2=Krastel|first2=Kirsten|last3=Cvitkovitch|first3=Dennis G.|date=2005-07-01|title=Transport and metabolism of citrate by Streptococcus mutans|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=187|issue=13|pages=4451–4456|doi=10.1128/JB.187.13.4451-4456.2005|issn=0021-9193|pmc=1151779|pmid=15968054}}</ref>
The transport reactions catalyzed by (1) CitM and (2) CitH, respectively, are:
(1) Citrate • Mg (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Citrate • Mg (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in)
(2) Citrate (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Citrate (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in)
(3) Citrate • Ca<sup>2+</sup> (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) ⇌ Citrate • Ca<sup>2+</sup> (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in)

The '''NhaB family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.34 TC# 2.A.34]) belongs to the [[Ion transporter|Ion Transporter (IT) Superfamily]].{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}} A representative list of proteins belonging to the NhaB family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.34.1 Transporter Classification Database]. NhaB homologues are usually about 500 amino acyl residues (aas) in length and possess about 12 transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs), although some members differ in their number of TMSs. NhaB homologues also exhibit a region with limited sequence similarity to a 46 kDa membrane protein of unknown function from ''[[Mycobacterium leprae]]'' (spP46838) which is also homologous to a member of arsenate resistance pumps of bacteria, archaea and eukaryotes ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.a.4 TC# 3.A.4]). Only [[Gram-negative bacteria|Gram-negative]] bacterial proteins have been functionally characterized. The ''E. coli'' NhaB is 58% identical to the orthologous ''[[Vibrio alginolyticus]]'' Na+/H+ antiporter.{{Cite journal|last=Pinner|first=E.|last2=Padan|first2=E.|last3=Schuldiner|first3=S.|date=1992-06-05|title=Cloning, sequencing, and expression of the nhaB gene, encoding a Na+/H+ antiporter in Escherichia coli|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|volume=267|issue=16|pages=11064–11068|issn=0021-9258|pmid=1317851}} Although the latter protein is predicted to exhibit 10 TMSs, construction of ''NhaB-phoA'' fusions led to evidence for a 9 TMS model with the N-terminus in the cytoplasm and the C-terminus in the [[periplasm]].{{Cite journal|last=Enomoto|first=H.|last2=Unemoto|first2=T.|last3=Nishibuchi|first3=M.|last4=Padan|first4=E.|last5=Nakamura|first5=T.|date=1998-03-06|title=Topological study of Vibrio alginolyticus NhaB Na+/H+ antiporter using gene fusions in Escherichia coli cells|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1370|issue=1|pages=77–86|issn=0006-3002|pmid=9518558|doi=10.1016/s0005-2736(97)00245-9}} A centrally located aspartyl residue in the 3rd TMS is conserved in all members of the family and important for activity.{{Cite journal|last=Nakamura|first=T.|last2=Fujisaki|first2=Y.|last3=Enomoto|first3=H.|last4=Nakayama|first4=Y.|last5=Takabe|first5=T.|last6=Yamaguchi|first6=N.|last7=Uozumi|first7=N.|date=2001-10-01|title=Residue aspartate-147 from the third transmembrane region of Na(+)/H(+) antiporter NhaB of Vibrio alginolyticus plays a role in its activity|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=183|issue=19|pages=5762–5767|doi=10.1128/JB.183.19.5762-5767.2001|issn=0021-9193|pmc=95471|pmid=11544242}} The generalized transport reaction catalyzed by NhaB of ''E. coli'' is:
2 Na+ (in) + 3 H+ (out) ⇌ 2 Na+ (out) + 3 H+ (in).

The '''NhaC family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.35 TC# 2.A.35]) belongs to the [[Ion transporter|Ion Transporter (IT) Superfamily]].{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}} A representative list of proteins belonging to the NhaC family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.35.3 Transporter Classification Database]. Two members of the NhaC family have been functionally characterized. One is believed to be a Na+:H+ antiporter;{{Cite journal|last=Ito|first=M.|last2=Guffanti|first2=A. A.|last3=Zemsky|first3=J.|last4=Ivey|first4=D. M.|last5=Krulwich|first5=T. A.|date=1997-06-01|title=Role of the nhaC-encoded Na+/H+ antiporter of alkaliphilic Bacillus firmus OF4|journal=Journal of Bacteriology|volume=179|issue=12|pages=3851–3857|issn=0021-9193|pmc=179192|pmid=9190799|doi=10.1128/jb.179.12.3851-3857.1997}} the other is a malate·H+:lactate·Na+ antiporter.{{Cite journal|last=Wei|first=Y.|last2=Guffanti|first2=A. A.|last3=Ito|first3=M.|last4=Krulwich|first4=T. A.|date=2000-09-29|title=Bacillus subtilis YqkI is a novel malic/Na+-lactate antiporter that enhances growth on malate at low protonmotive force|journal=The Journal of Biological Chemistry|volume=275|issue=39|pages=30287–30292|doi=10.1074/jbc.M001112200|issn=0021-9258|pmid=10903309}} Several paralogues are found in ''[[Vibrio cholerae]],'' and two paralogues are found encoded in the completely sequenced genomes of both''[[Haemophilus influenzae]]'' and ''[[Bacillus subtilis]].'' ''[[Escherichia coli|E. coli]]'' lacks such a homologue. ''[[Pyrococcus]]'' species also have at least one homologue each. Thus, members of the NhaC family are found in both [[Gram-negative bacteria]] and [[Gram-positive bacteria]] as well as archaea. NhaC of ''B. firmus'' is 462 amino acyl residues long and possesses 12 putative transmembrane α-helical segments. MleN of ''B. subtilis'' (468 aas; [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.35.1.2 TC# 2.A.35.1.2]) also exhibits 12 putative TMSs. The transport reaction catalyzed by NhaC is probably:
Na+ (in) + nH+ (out) ⇌ Na+ (out) + nH+ (in). (n > 1)
That catalyzed by MleN is probably:
Malate (out) + H+ (out) + Lactate (in) + Na+ (in) ⇌ Malate (in) + H+ (in) + Lactate (out) + Na+ (out)

The '''NhaD family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.62 TC# 2.A.62]) belongs to the [[Ion transporter|Ion Transporter (IT) Superfamily]].{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}} A representative list of proteins belonging to the NhaD family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.62.1 Transporter Classification Database]. The NhaD Na+/H+ antiporter has been characterized from two ''Vibrio'' species: ''[[Vibrio parahaemolyticus|V. parahaemolyticus]]'' and ''[[Vibrio cholerae|V. cholerae]]'' and in the haloalkaliphile, ''[[Alkalimonas amylolytica]]''.{{Cite journal|last=Nozaki|first=K.|last2=Kuroda|first2=T.|last3=Mizushima|first3=T.|last4=Tsuchiya|first4=T.|date=1998-03-02|title=A new Na+/H+ antiporter, NhaD, of Vibrio parahaemolyticus|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1369|issue=2|pages=213–220|issn=0006-3002|pmid=9518619|doi=10.1016/s0005-2736(97)00223-x}}{{Cite journal|last=Ostroumov|first=Elena|last2=Dzioba|first2=Judith|last3=Loewen|first3=Peter C.|last4=Dibrov|first4=Pavel|date=2002-08-19|title=Asp(344) and Thr(345) are critical for cation exchange mediated by NhaD, Na(+)/H(+) antiporter of Vibrio cholerae|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1564|issue=1|pages=99–106|issn=0006-3002|pmid=12101001|doi=10.1016/s0005-2736(02)00407-8}} These proteins and their homologues are 400-500 aas long and exhibit 10-13 TMSs. They catalyze Na+/H+ and Li+/H+ antiport. They exhibit activity at basic pH (8-10) with no activity at pH 7.5. The ''Amylolytica'' antiporter has low Na+ affinity and has optimal activity at 600 mM Na+. Homologues are found in proteobacteria of all groups, ''[[Flavobacteriia|Flavobacteria]]'' and ''[[Chlamydiae|Chlamydia]].'' Distant homologues of the [[Ion transporter|IT superfamily]] are ubiquitous. The generalized reaction catalyzed by NhaD is:
nH+ (in) + mNa+ (out) ⇌ nH+ (out) + mNa+ (in).

The '''NhaE family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.111 TC# 2.A.111]) belongs to the [[Ion transporter|Ion Transporter (IT) Superfamily]].{{Cite journal|last=Prakash|first=Shraddha|last2=Cooper|first2=Garret|last3=Singhi|first3=Soumya|last4=Saier|first4=Milton H.|date=2003-12-03|title=The ion transporter superfamily|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta|volume=1618|issue=1|pages=79–92|issn=0006-3002|pmid=14643936|doi=10.1016/j.bbamem.2003.10.010}}{{Cite journal|last=Lolkema|first=Juke S.|last2=Slotboom|first2=Dirk Jan|date=2003-04-11|title=Classification of 29 families of secondary transport proteins into a single structural class using hydropathy profile analysis|journal=Journal of Molecular Biology|volume=327|issue=5|pages=901–909|issn=0022-2836|pmid=12662917|doi=10.1016/s0022-2836(03)00214-6|url=https://pure.rug.nl/ws/files/6669968/2003JMolBiolLolkema.pdf}}{{Cite journal|last=Rabus|first=R.|last2=Jack|first2=D. L.|last3=Kelly|first3=D. J.|last4=Saier|first4=M. H.|date=1999-12-01|title=TRAP transporters: an ancient family of extracytoplasmic solute-receptor-dependent secondary active transporters|journal=Microbiology|volume=145 ( Pt 12)|issue=12|pages=3431–3445|doi=10.1099/00221287-145-12-3431|issn=1350-0872|pmid=10627041}} A representative list of proteins belonging to the NhaE family can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.111.2 Transporter Classification Database]. The NhaH family consists of proteins from Gram-negative bacteria (e.g., ''[[Leptospira]]'', ''[[Azotobacter]]'', ''[[Neisseria]]'', ''[[Ralstonia]]'', ''[[Chlorobium]]'' and ''[[Rhizobia]]l'' species). The proteins are of about 480 aas with 12-14 putative TMSs. An open reading frame (ORF) from the genome of ''[[Neisseria meningitidis]]'' displaying similarity with the NhaE type of Na+/H+ antiporters was expressed in ''E. coli'' and characterized for sodium transport ability. The ''N. meningitidis'' antiporter (NmNhaE) was able to complement an ''E. coli'' strain devoid of Na+/H+ antiporters (KNabc) with respect to the ability to grow in the presence of high concentrations of NaCl or LiCl. Ion transport assays in everted vesicles prepared from the KNabc strain expressing NmNhaE from a plasmid confirmed its ability to translocate Na+ and Li+.{{Cite journal|last=Sousa|first=Pedro M. F.|last2=Videira|first2=Marco A. M.|last3=Vorburger|first3=Thomas|last4=Silva|first4=Sara T. N.|last5=Moir|first5=James W.|last6=Steuber|first6=Julia|last7=Melo|first7=Ana M. P.|date=2013-03-01|title=The novel NhaE-type Na(+)/H (+) antiporter of the pathogenic bacterium Neisseria meningitidis|journal=Archives of Microbiology|volume=195|issue=3|pages=211–217|doi=10.1007/s00203-012-0856-4|issn=1432-072X|pmid=23208205}} The generalized reaction catalyzed by NhaE is,
Na+ or Li+ (in) + H+ (out) ⇌ Na+ or Li+ (out) + H+ (in)

The '''Monovalent Cation (K+ or Na+):Proton Antiporter-3 (CPA3) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.63 TC# 2.A.63]) is a member of the [[Mrp superfamily|Na+ transporting Mrp superfamily]]. The CPA3 family consists of bacterial multicomponent K+:H+ and Na+:H+ [[antiporter]]s. The best characterized systems are the PhaABCDEFG system of ''[[Sinorhizobium meliloti]]'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.63.1.1 TC# 2.A.63.1.1]) that functions in pH adaptation and as a K+ efflux system, and the MnhABCDEFG system of ''[[Staphylococcus aureus]]'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.63.1.3 TC# 2.A.63.1.3]) that functions as a Na+ efflux Na+:H+ antiporter.{{Cite web|url=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.63|title=2.A.63 The Monovalent Cation (K+ or Na+):Proton Antiporter-3 (CPA3) Family|website=Transporter Classification Databse|access-date=2016-03-16}} == Homology == A homologous, but only partially sequenced, system was earlier reported to catalyze Na+:H+ antiport in an alkalophilic ''[[Bacillus]]'' strain. PhaA and PhaD are respectively homologous to the ND5 and ND4 subunits of the H+-pumping [[NADH:ubiquinone oxidoreductase]] ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.d.1 TC #3.D.1]). Homologous protein subunits from ''[[Escherichia coli|E. coli]]'' NADH:quinone oxidoreductase can functionally replace MrpA and MrpD in ''[[Bacillus subtilis]].''{{cite journal | vauthors = Moparthi VK, Kumar B, Mathiesen C, Hägerhäll C | title = Homologous protein subunits from Escherichia coli NADH:quinone oxidoreductase can functionally replace MrpA and MrpD in Bacillus subtilis | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1807 | issue = 4 | pages = 427–36 | date = April 2011 | pmid = 21236240 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbabio.2011.01.005 }} Homologues of PhaA, B, C and D and Nha1, 2, 3 and 4 of an alkalophilic ''Bacillus'' strain are the Yuf(Mrp)T, U, V and D genes of ''Bacillus subtilis''. In this system, YufT is believed to be responsible for Na+:H+ antiporter activity, but it does not have activity in the absence of other constituents of the operon.{{cite journal | vauthors = Kosono S, Morotomi S, Kitada M, Kudo T | title = Analyses of a Bacillus subtilis homologue of the Na+/H+ antiporter gene which is important for pH homeostasis of alkaliphilic Bacillus sp. C-125 | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1409 | issue = 3 | pages = 171–5 | date = January 1999 | pmid = 9878723 | doi = 10.1016/s0005-2728(98)00157-1 }} == Structure == The seven Pha proteins are of the following sizes (in #aas) and exhibit the following putative numbers of transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs): * PhaA - 725 and 17 * PhaB - 257 and 5 * PhaC - 115 and 3 * PhaD - 547 and 13 * PhaE - 161 and 3 * PhaF - 92 and 3 * PhaG - 120 and 3 All are predicted to be integral membrane proteins. Corresponding values for the ''[[Staphylococcus aureus|S. aureus]]'' Mnh system are:{{cite journal | vauthors = Hiramatsu T, Kodama K, Kuroda T, Mizushima T, Tsuchiya T | title = A putative multisubunit Na+/H+ antiporter from Staphylococcus aureus | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 180 | issue = 24 | pages = 6642–8 | date = December 1998 | pmid = 9852009 | pmc = 107768 }} * MnhA - 801 and 18 * MnhB - 142 and 4 * MnhC - 113 and 3 * MnhD - 498 and 13 * MnhE - 159 and 4 * MnhF - 97 and 3 * MnhG - 118 and 3 In view of the complexity of the system, large variation in subunit structure, and the homology with NDH family protein constituents, a complicated energy coupling mechanism, possibly involving a redox reaction, cannot be ruled out. == Function == Na+ or Li+ does, but K+, Ca2+, and Mg2+ do not, support significant [[Antiporter|antiport]] by the [[Gram-positive bacteria]]l systems (TC# 2.A.6.3.1.2 and TC# 2.A.6.3.1.3).{{cite journal | vauthors = Swartz TH, Ito M, Ohira T, Natsui S, Hicks DB, Krulwich TA | title = Catalytic properties of Staphylococcus aureus and Bacillus members of the secondary cation/proton antiporter-3 (Mrp) family are revealed by an optimized assay in an Escherichia coli host | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 189 | issue = 8 | pages = 3081–90 | date = April 2007 | pmid = 17293423 | pmc = 1855852 | doi = 10.1128/JB.00021-07 }} Na+(Li+)/H+ antiporters have alkaline pH optima and apparent Km values for Na+ that are among the lowest reported for bacterial Na+/H+ antiporters. Na+/H+antiport consumes the pmf and therefore is probably electrogenic. YufF (MrpF) appears to catalyze [[Cholic acid|cholate]] efflux, possibly by a Na+ symport mechanism.{{cite journal | vauthors = Ito M, Guffanti AA, Wang W, Krulwich TA | title = Effects of nonpolar mutations in each of the seven Bacillus subtilis mrp genes suggest complex interactions among the gene products in support of Na(+) and alkali but not cholate resistance | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 182 | issue = 20 | pages = 5663–70 | date = October 2000 | pmid = 11004162 | pmc = 94685 | doi = 10.1128/jb.182.20.5663-5670.2000 }} It plays a major role in Na+ extrusion and is required for initiation of sporulation.{{cite journal | vauthors = Kosono S, Ohashi Y, Kawamura F, Kitada M, Kudo T | title = Function of a principal Na(+)/H(+) antiporter, ShaA, is required for initiation of sporulation in Bacillus subtilis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 182 | issue = 4 | pages = 898–904 | date = February 2000 | pmid = 10648512 | pmc = 94362 | doi = 10.1128/jb.182.4.898-904.2000 }}{{cite journal | vauthors = Ito M, Guffanti AA, Oudega B, Krulwich TA | title = mrp, a multigene, multifunctional locus in Bacillus subtilis with roles in resistance to cholate and to Na+ and in pH homeostasis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 181 | issue = 8 | pages = 2394–402 | date = April 1999 | pmid = 10198001 | pmc = 93663 }} Additionally, another component of the operon, MrpF (equivalent to PhaF of ''R. meliloti'') has been implicated in choline and Na+ efflux. The MrpA-G proteins of ''B. subtilis'' have been shown to be present in a single multicomponent complex.{{cite journal | vauthors = Kajiyama Y, Otagiri M, Sekiguchi J, Kosono S, Kudo T | title = Complex formation by the mrpABCDEFG gene products, which constitute a principal Na+/H+ antiporter in Bacillus subtilis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 189 | issue = 20 | pages = 7511–4 | date = October 2007 | pmid = 17693497 | pmc = 2168430 | doi = 10.1128/JB.00968-07 }} They provide Na+/H+ antiport activity and function in multiple compound resistance and pH homeostasis. === Transport Reaction === The generalized reaction believed to be catalyzed by CPA3 family members is:
[K+ or Na+] (in) + H+ (out) ⇌ [K+ or Na+] (out) + H+ (in).
== See also == * [[Sodium-Proton antiporter]] * [[Monovalent cation:Proton antiporter-1|Monovalent Cation (K+ or Na+):Proton Antiporter-1]] * [[Monovalent cation:Proton antiporter-2|Monovalent Cation (K+ or Na+):Proton Antiporter-2]] * [[Transporter Classification Database]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Portal bar|Biology|border=no}} {{CCBYSASource|sourcepath=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.63|sourcearticle=2.A.63 The Monovalent Cation (K+ or Na+):Proton Antiporter-3 (CPA3) Family|revision=699838558}} [[Category:Biology]] [[Category:Protein families]] [[Category:Membrane proteins]] [[Category:Transmembrane proteins]] [[Category:Transmembrane transporters]] [[Category:Transport proteins]] [[Category:Integral membrane proteins]]

revision.comment: Disambiguation, although in a somewhat counterintuititive way, as the [[Centimorgan]] is a unit of measurement of distance of DNA, but that article seems to best describe the meaning
revision.text:
In [[comparative genomics]], a '''sequence graph''', also called an '''alignment graph''', '''breakpoint graph''', or '''adjacency graph''', is a [[bidirected graph]] in which the vertices represent segments of [[Deoxyribonucleic Acid|DNA]] and the edges represent [[Centimorgan|adjacency]] between segments in a [[genome]]. <ref>{{cite journal | last=Alekseyev | first=M. A. | last2=Pevzner | first2=P. A. | title=Breakpoint graphs and ancestral genome reconstructions | journal=Genome Research | publisher=Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory | volume=19 | issue=5 | date=2009-02-13 | issn=1088-9051 | pmid=19218533 | pmc=2675983 | doi=10.1101/gr.082784.108 | pages=943–957 | ref=harv}}</ref> The segments are labeled by the DNA string they represent, and each edge connects the tail end of one segment with the head end of another segment. Each adjacency edge is labelled by a (possibly empty) string of DNA. Traversing a connected component of segments and adjacency edges (called a ''thread'') yields a sequence, which typically represents a genome or a section of a genome. The segments can be thought of as [[synteny]] blocks, with the edges dictating how to arrange these blocks in a particular genome, and the labelling of the adjacency edges representing bases that are not contained in synteny blocks.
==Applications== ===Multiple sequence alignment=== Sequence graphs can be used to represent [[multiple sequence alignment|multiple sequence alignments]] with the addition of a new kind of edge representing [[homology (biology)|homology]] between segments. <ref>{{cite journal | last=Paten | first=Benedict | last2=Zerbino | first2=Daniel R | last3=Hickey | first3=Glenn | last4=Haussler | first4=David | title=A unifying model of genome evolution under parsimony | journal=[[BMC Bioinformatics]] | publisher=Springer Science and Business Media LLC | volume=15 | issue=1 | date=2014-06-19 | issn=1471-2105 | doi=10.1186/1471-2105-15-206 | ref=harv}}</ref> For a set of genomes, one can create an acyclic breakpoint graph with a thread for each genome. For two segments <math>(a, b)</math> and <math>(c,d)</math>, where <math>a</math>,<math>b</math>,<math>c</math>, and <math>d</math> represent the endpoints of the two segments, homology edges can be created from <math>a</math> to <math>c</math> and <math>b</math> to <math>d</math> or from <math>a</math> to <math>d</math> and <math>b</math> to <math>c</math> - representing the two possible orientations of the homology. The advantage of representing a multiple sequence alignment this way is that it is possible to include inversions and other structural rearrangements that wouldn't be allowable in a matrix representation.
===Representing variation=== If there are multiple possible paths when traversing a thread in a sequence graph, multiple sequences can be represented by the same thread. This means it is possible to create a sequence graph that represents a population of individuals with slightly different genomes - with each genome corresponding to one path through the graph. These graphs have been proposed as a replacement for the [[reference genome|reference]] [[human genome]]. <ref> {{cite web | last=Paten | first=Benedict | last2=Novak | first2=Adam | last3=Haussler | first3=David | title=Mapping to a Reference Genome Structure | website=[[arXiv.org]] | date=2014-04-20 | url=https://arxiv.org/abs/1404.5010v1 | ref=harv | access-date=2019-09-25}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Pfam_box|Symbol=|Name=H+, Na+-translocating pyrophosphatase|image=|width=|caption=|Pfam=PF03030|InterPro=IPR004131|SMART=|Prosite=|SCOP=|TCDB=3.A.10|OPM family=390|OPM protein=4av3|PDB=}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:H+, Na+-translocating pyrophosphatase family}} Members of the '''H+, Na+-translocating Pyrophosphatase (M+''-PPase)'' Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.a.10 TC# 3.A.10]) are found in the vacuolar ([[Vacuole|tonoplast]]) membranes of higher plants, [[algae]], and [[protozoa]], and in both bacteria and [[archaea]]. They are therefore ancient enzymes. Two types of [[inorganic diphosphatase]], very different in terms of both [[amino acid sequence]] and [[Protein structure, secondary|structure]], have been characterised to date: soluble and [[transmembrane]] '''proton-pumping pyrophosphatases''' (sPPases and H(+)-PPases, respectively). sPPases are ubiquitous [[protein]]s that hydrolyse [[pyrophosphate]] to release heat, whereas H+-PPases, so far unidentified in [[animal]] and [[fungus|fungal]] cells, couple the energy of PPi [[hydrolysis]] to [[proton]] movement across [[biology|biological]] [[Cell membrane|membrane]]s.{{cite journal |vauthors=Perez-Castineira JR, Lopez-Marques RL, Villalba JM, Losada M, Serrano A | title = Functional complementation of yeast cytosolic pyrophosphatase by bacterial and plant H+-translocating pyrophosphatases | journal = Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. | volume = 99 | issue = 25 | pages = 15914–9 |date=December 2002 | pmid = 12451180 | pmc = 138539 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.242625399 | url = | hdl = 11441/26079 }}{{cite journal |vauthors=Baltscheffsky M, Schultz A, Baltscheffsky H | title = H+ -PPases: a tightly membrane-bound family | journal = FEBS Lett. | volume = 457 | issue = 3 | pages = 527–33 |date=September 1999 | pmid = 10523139 | doi = 10.1016/S0014-5793(99)90617-8| url = }} The latter type is represented by this group of [[proteins]]. H+-PPases [[vacuolar]]-type inorganic pyrophosphatases (V-PPase) or pyrophosphate-energised vacuolar membrane [[proton pump]]s.{{cite journal |vauthors=Perez-Castineira JR, Lopez-Marques RL, Losada M, Serrano A | title = A thermostable K(+)-stimulated vacuolar-type pyrophosphatase from the hyperthermophilic bacterium Thermotoga maritima | journal = FEBS Lett. | volume = 496 | issue = 1 | pages = 6–11 |date=May 2001 | pmid = 11343697 | doi = 10.1016/S0014-5793(01)02390-0| url = }} In plants, vacuoles contain two [[enzyme]]s for acidifying the interior of the vacuole, the [[V-ATPase]] and the V-PPase (V is for vacuolar). Two distinct [[Biochemistry|biochemical]] subclasses of H+-PPases have been characterised to date: [[Potassium|K]]+-stimulated and K+-insensitive. == Classification == Full-length members of the H+-PPase family have been sequenced from numerous bacteria, archaea and eukaryotes. These H+ pumping enzymes, which are probably homodimeric, have been reported to fall into two phylogenetic subfamilies.{{cite journal | vauthors = Belogurov GA, Turkina MV, Penttinen A, Huopalahti S, Baykov AA, Lahti R | title = H+-pyrophosphatase of Rhodospirillum rubrum. High yield expression in Escherichia coli and identification of the Cys residues responsible for inactivation my mersalyl | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 277 | issue = 25 | pages = 22209–14 | date = June 2002 | pmid = 11956221 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M202951200 }} One subfamily invariably contains a conserved cysteine (Cys222) and includes all known K+-independent H+-PPases, while the other has another conserved cysteine (Cys573) but lacks Cys222 and includes all known K+-dependent H+-PPases.{{cite journal | vauthors = Belogurov GA, Fabrichniy IP, Pohjanjoki P, Kasho VN, Lehtihuhta E, Turkina MV, Cooperman BS, Goldman A, Baykov AA, Lahti R | title = Catalytically important ionizations along the reaction pathway of yeast pyrophosphatase | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 39 | issue = 45 | pages = 13931–8 | date = November 2000 | pmid = 11076535 | doi = 10.1021/bi000895s }} All H+-PPases require Mg2+, and those from plant vacuoles, acidocalcisomes of protozoa and fermentative bacteria require mM K+. Those from respiratory and photosynthetic bacteria as well as archaea are less dependent upon K+. However, exceptions may exist. It is not sure whether K+ is transported. The archaeon, ''[[Methanosarcina]]'' ''mazei'' Gö1, encodes within its genome two H+-translocating [[pyrophosphatase]]s (PPases), Mvp1 and Mvp2. Mvp1 resembles bacterial PPases while Mvp2 resembles plant PPases.{{cite journal | vauthors = Bäumer S, Lentes S, Gottschalk G, Deppenmeier U | title = Identification and analysis of proton-translocating pyrophosphatases in the methanogenic archaeon Methansarcina mazei | journal = Archaea | volume = 1 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–7 | date = March 2002 | pmid = 15803653 | pmc = 2685546 | doi = 10.1155/2002/371325 }} Mvp2 was shown to translocate 1 H+ per pyrophosphate hydrolyzed. Some PPases from ''[[Anaerostipes caccae]]'', ''Chlorobium limicola'', ''[[Clostridium tetani]]'', and ''[[Desulfuromonas acetoxidans]]'' have been identified as K+-dependent Na+ transporters.{{cite journal | vauthors = Luoto HH, Belogurov GA, Baykov AA, Lahti R, Malinen AM | title = Na+-translocating membrane pyrophosphatases are widespread in the microbial world and evolutionarily precede H+-translocating pyrophosphatases | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 286 | issue = 24 | pages = 21633–42 | date = June 2011 | pmid = 21527638 | pmc = 3283130 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M111.244483 }} Phylogenetic analysis led to the identification of a monophyletic clade comprising characterized and predicted Na+-transporting PPases (Na+-PPases) within the K+-dependent subfamily. H+-transporting PPases (H+-PPases) are more heterogeneous and form at least three independent clades in both subfamilies. == Function == The plant enzymes probably pump one H+ upon hydrolysis of pyrophosphate, thereby generating a [[proton motive force]], positive and acidic in the tonoplast lumen. They establish a pmf of similar magnitude to that generated by the H+-translocating ATPases in the same vacuolar membrane. The bacterial and archaeal proteins may catalyze fully reversible reactions, thus being able to synthesize pyrophosphate when the pmf is sufficient. The enzyme from ''R. rubrum'' contributes to the pmf when light intensity is insufficient to generate a pmf sufficient in magnitude to support rapid ATP synthesis. Both C-termini of the [[Protein dimer|dimeric]] subunits of V-PPase are on the same side of the membrane, and they are close to each other.{{cite journal | vauthors = Liu TH, Hsu SH, Huang YT, Lin SM, Huang TW, Chuang TH, Fan SK, Fu CC, Tseng FG, Pan RL | title = The proximity between C-termini of dimeric vacuolar H+-pyrophosphatase determined using atomic force microscopy and a gold nanoparticle technique | journal = The FEBS Journal | volume = 276 | issue = 16 | pages = 4381–94 | date = August 2009 | pmid = 19614743 | doi = 10.1111/j.1742-4658.2009.07146.x }} Transmembrane domain 6 of vacuolar H+-[[pyrophosphatase]] appears to mediate both protein targeting and proton transport.{{cite journal | vauthors = Pan YJ, Lee CH, Hsu SH, Huang YT, Lee CH, Liu TH, Chen YW, Lin SM, Pan RL | title = The transmembrane domain 6 of vacuolar H(+)-pyrophosphatase mediates protein targeting and proton transport | journal = Biochimica et Biophysica Acta | volume = 1807 | issue = 1 | pages = 59–67 | date = January 2011 | pmid = 20937245 | doi = 10.1016/j.bbabio.2010.10.006 }} The generalized transport reaction catalyzed by H+-PPases is:
pyrophosphate (P2) + H2O + H+ (cytoplasm) → inorganic phosphate (2 Pi) + H+ (external milieu or vacuolar lumen).
== Structure == Eukaryotic members of the H+-PPase family are large proteins of about 770 amino acyl residues (aas) with 15 or 16 putative transmembrane α-helical spanners (TMSs). The N-termini are predicted to be in the vacuolar lumen while the C-termini are thought to be in the cytoplasm. These proteins exhibit a region that shows convincing sequence similarity to the regions surrounding the DCCD-sensitive glutamate in the C-terminal regions of the c-subunits of F-type ATPases ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.A.2 TC #3.A.2]). The H+-pyrophosphatase of ''[[Streptomyces coelicolor]]'' has been shown to have a 17 TMS topology with the substrate binding domain exposed to the cytoplasm. The C-terminus is hydrophilic with a single C-terminal TMS. The basic structure is believed to have 16 TMSs with several large cytoplasmic loops containing functional motifs.{{cite journal | vauthors = Mimura H, Nakanishi Y, Hirono M, Maeshima M | title = Membrane topology of the H+-pyrophosphatase of Streptomyces coelicolor determined by cysteine-scanning mutagenesis | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 33 | pages = 35106–12 | date = August 2004 | pmid = 15187077 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M406264200 }} Several acidic residues in the ''[[Arabidopsis]]'' H+-PPase have been shown to be important for function. Some plants possess closely related H+-PPase isoforms. These enzymes have the enzyme commission number [[EC 3.6.1.1]]. Lin et al. (2012) reported the crystal structure of a ''[[Vigna radiata]]'' H+-PPase (VrH+-PPase) in complex with a non-hydrolysable substrate analogue, imidodiphosphate (IDP), at 2.35 Å resolution. Each VrH+-PPase subunit consists of an integral membrane domain formed by 16 transmembrane helices.{{cite journal | vauthors = Lin SM, Tsai JY, Hsiao CD, Huang YT, Chiu CL, Liu MH, Tung JY, Liu TH, Pan RL, Sun YJ | title = Crystal structure of a membrane-embedded H+-translocating pyrophosphatase | journal = Nature | volume = 484 | issue = 7394 | pages = 399–403 | date = March 2012 | pmid = 22456709 | doi = 10.1038/nature10963 }} IDP is bound in the cytosolic region of each subunit and trapped by numerous charged residues and five Mg2+ ions. A previously undescribed proton translocation pathway is formed by six core transmembrane helices. Proton pumping can be initialized by PP(i) hydrolysis, and H+ is then transported into the vacuolar lumen through a pathway consisting of Arg 242, Asp 294, Lys 742 and Glu 301. Lin et al. (2012) proposed a working model of the mechanism for the coupling between proton pumping and PP(i) hydrolysis by H+-PPases. Membrane-integral pyrophosphatases (M-PPases) are crucial for the survival of plants, bacteria, and protozoan parasites. They couple pyrophosphate hydrolysis or synthesis to Na+ or H+ pumping. The 2.6Å structure of ''[[Thermotoga maritima]]'' H+-PPase in the resting state revealed a previously unknown solution for ion pumping.{{cite journal | vauthors = Kellosalo J, Kajander T, Kogan K, Pokharel K, Goldman A | title = The structure and catalytic cycle of a sodium-pumping pyrophosphatase | journal = Science | volume = 337 | issue = 6093 | pages = 473–6 | date = July 2012 | pmid = 22837527 | doi = 10.1126/science.1222505 }} The hydrolytic center, 20 angstroms above the membrane, is coupled to the gate formed by the conserved Asp(243), Glu(246), and Lys(707) by an unusual 'coupling funnel' of six α helices. Helix 12 slides down upon substrate binding to open the gate by a simple binding-change mechanism. Below the gate, four helices form the exit channel. Superimposing helices 3 to 6, 9 to 12, and 13 to 16 suggests that M-PPases arose through gene triplication. By comparing the active sites, fluoride inhibition data and the various models for ion transport, Kajander et al. concluded that membrane-integral PPases probably use binding of pyrophosphate to drive pumping.{{cite journal | vauthors = Kajander T, Kellosalo J, Goldman A | title = Inorganic pyrophosphatases: one substrate, three mechanisms | journal = FEBS Letters | volume = 587 | issue = 13 | pages = 1863–9 | date = June 2013 | pmid = 23684653 | doi = 10.1016/j.febslet.2013.05.003 }} == See also == * [[Phosphate permease]] * [[Pyrophosphatase]] == References == {{Reflist|32em}} {{Portal bar|Biology|border=no}} {{InterPro content|IPR004131}} {{CCBYSASource|sourcepath=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=3.a.10|sourcearticle=3.A.10 The H+, Na+-translocating Pyrophosphatase (M+-PPase) Family|revision=699838558}} [[Category:Biology]] [[Category:Protein families]] [[Category:Membrane proteins]] [[Category:Transmembrane proteins]] [[Category:Transmembrane transporters]] [[Category:Transport proteins]] [[Category:Integral membrane proteins]]

[[File:Hydras (8).JPG|thumb|upright|Generally sessile ''[[Hydra (genus)|Hydra]]'' attached to a substrate]]
'''Sessility''' is the [[biology|biological]] property of an [[organism]] describing its lack of a means of self-locomotion. Absent natural ''[[motility]]'' sessile organisms are normally immobile. This is distinct from the [[sessility (botany)|botanical]] meaning of sessility, which refers to an organism or biological structure attached directly by its base without a stalk.
Sessile organisms can move via external forces (such as water currents), but are usually permanently attached to something. Organisms such as [[coral]]s lay down their own [[substrate (biology)|substrate]] from which they grow. Other sessile organisms grow from a solid such as a rock, dead tree trunk, or a manmade object such as a buoy or ship's hull.<ref>{{citebook|title=Biology of the Invertebrates|last=Pechenik|first=Jan|date=2016|ISBN=9781497006515}}</ref>
==Mobility== Sessile animals typically have a motile phase in their development. [[Sponge]]s have a motile [[larval]] stage, which becomes sessile at maturity. In contrast, many [[jellyfish]] develop as sessile [[polyp (zoology)|polyp]]s early in their life cycle. In the case of the [[cochineal]], it is in the nymph stage (also called the crawler stage) that the cochineal disperses. The juveniles move to a feeding spot and produce long wax filaments. Later they move to the edge of the cactus pad where the wind catches the wax filaments and carries the tiny larval cochineals to a new host.
==Reproduction== Many sessile animals, including sponges, [[coral]]s and [[hydra (genus)|hydra]], are capable of [[asexual reproduction]] ''[[in situ]]'' by the process of [[budding]]. Sessile organisms such as [[barnacle]]s and [[tunicate]]s need some mechanism to move their young into new territory. This is why the most widely accepted theory explaining the [[evolution]] of a [[larva]]l stage is the need for long-distance dispersal ability. Biologist [[Wayne Sousa]]'s 1979 study in intertidal disturbance added support for the theory of nonequilibrium community structure, “suggesting that open space is necessary for the maintenance of diversity in most communities of sessile organisms.”<ref>WP. Ecology. 1979. Disturbance in Marine Intertidal Boulder Fields: The Nonequilibrium maintenance of species diversity. http://bio.classes.ucsc.edu/bio170/Readings/sousa%201979.pdf</ref>
==Clumping== {{Main Article|Clumping (biology)}} [[File:Blue mussel clump.jpg|thumb|280px|Blue mussels, ''[[Mytilus edulis]]'', are sessile and exhibit clumping]]
'''Clumping''' is a behavior in sessile organisms, in which individuals of a particular species group closely to one another for beneficial purposes, and can be seen in [[coral reef]]s and cochineal populations. This allows for faster reproduction and better protection from predators.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ecology and Classification of North American Freshwater Invertebrates|author=James H. Thorp|author2=Alan P. Covich |publisher=[[Academic Press]]|page=213|date=2001|isbn=0-12-690647-5|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aj2ZMSekmHEC&dq=Sessile+Limnology&source=gbs_navlinks_s}}</ref>
==Predominance in coastal environments== The [[littoral zone|circalittoral zone]] of [[coast]]al environments and [[biome]]s are dominated by sessile organisms such as [[oyster]]s. [[Carbonate platform]]s grow due to the buildup of skeletal remains of sessile organisms, usually [[microorganism]]s, which induce carbonate precipitation through their metabolism.
==Botanical sessility== In anatomy and botany, ''sessility'' refers to an organism or biological structure that has no ''peduncle'' or stalk. See [[peduncle (anatomy)]], [[peduncle (botany)]] and [[sessility (botany)]]. A sessile structure has no stalk.
==See also== * [[Anthozoa]] * [[Ediacara biota]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}} [[Category:Animal locomotion]] [[Category:Zoology]] [[Category:Biology]]

'''Phylogenetic inertia''' or phylogenetic constraint refers to the limitations on the future [[evolution]]ary pathways that have been imposed by previous [[adaptation]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=K|last2=McKinney|first2=F|last3=Sorenson|first3=M|date=1999|title=Phylogenetic constraint on male parental care in the dabbling ducks.|url=|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B|volume=266|issue=1421|pages=759–763|doi=10.1098/rspb.1999.0702|pmid=|pmc=1689901}}</ref>
[[Charles Darwin]] first recognized this phenomenon, though the term was later coined by Huber in 1939.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Huber|first=B|date=1939|title=Siebrohrensystem unserer Baume und seine jahreszeitlichen Veranderungen.|url=|journal=Jahrbücher für Wissenschaftliche Botanik|volume=88|pages=176–242|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> Darwin explained the idea of phylogenetic inertia based on his observations; he spoke about it when explaining the "Law of Conditions of Existence".<ref name=":4" /> Darwin also suggested that, after [[speciation]], the [[organism]]s do not start over from scratch, but have characteristics that are built upon already existing ones that were inherited from their ancestors; and these characteristics likely limit the amount of evolution seen in that new [[Taxon|taxa]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Shanahan|first=Timothy|date=2011|title=Phylogenetic Inertia and Darwin's Higher Law|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/49816525|journal=Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> This is the main concept of phylogenetic inertia.
[[Richard Dawkins]] also explained these constraints by likening [[natural selection]] to a river in his 1982 book ''[[The Extended Phenotype]]''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Extended Phenotype: The Gene as a Unit of Selection|last=Dawkins|first=Richard|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|year=1982|isbn=|location=|pages=42}}</ref>
== Examples of phylogenetic inertia ==
=== Body plan ===
*[[File:Fishapod evolution.jpg|alt=Sown here is a cladogram of the best known transitional fossils. From bottom to top: Eusthenopteron, Panderichthys, Tiktaalik, Acanthostega, Ichthyostega, Pederpes.|thumb|229x229px|Evolution of fish to tetrapods. The basic body plan has been phylogenetically constrained.]]Most terrestrial [[vertebrate]]s have a [[body plan]] that consist of four limbs. The phylogenetic inertia hypothesis suggests that this body plan is observed, not because it happens to be optimal, but because [[Evolution of tetrapods|tetrapods]] are derived from a [[clade]] of [[fish]]es ([[Sarcopterygii]]) which also have four limbs. Four limbs happened to be suitable means of locomotion, and so this body plan has not been selected against.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lewin|first=Roger|date=1980|title=Evolutionary Theory Under Fire|url=|journal=Science|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> * [[Human]]s do not have optimal structure for [[bipedalism]], because much of the human body plan originally evolved under [[Quadrupedalism|quadrupedal]] locomotion, and has since been constrained because of phylogenetic inertia.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gould|first=S. J.|last2=Lewontin|first2=R. C.|date=1979-09-21|title=The Spandrels of San Marco and the Panglossian Paradigm: A Critique of the Adaptationist Programme|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|volume=205|issue=1161|pages=581–598|doi=10.1098/rspb.1979.0086|issn=0962-8452|pmid=42062|bibcode=1979RSPSB.205..581G}}</ref>
=== Modes of reproduction ===
[[Bird]]s are the only speciose group of vertebrates that are exclusively [[Oviparity|oviparous]], or egg laying. It has been suggested that birds are phylogenetically constrained, as being derived from [[reptile]]s, and likely have not overcome this constraint or diverged far enough away to develop [[viviparity]], or live birth.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McKitrick|first=Mary|date=1993|title=Phylogenetic Constraint in Evolutionary Theory: Has it any Explanatory Power?|url=|journal=Annual Review of Ecology, Evolution, and Systematics|volume=24|pages=307–330|doi=10.1146/annurev.es.24.110193.001515}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Blackburn|first=Daniel|last2=Evans|first2=Howard|date=1986|title=Why are there no Viviparous Birds?|url=|journal=The American Naturalist|volume=128|issue=2|pages=165–190|doi=10.1086/284552}}</ref>
=== Homologous structures ===
* More specifically than the similarity in body plan, there are [[homology (biology)|homologous]] bones across [[mammal]]ian taxa. For example, the [[pentadactyl limb]] bone structure observed in the arms of [[primate]]s, front legs of equestrians, in the wings of [[bat]]s, and the flippers of [[Seal (animal)|seals]]. The fact that they are homologous is further evidence for phylogenetic inertia; these structures have been modified over time, but they are constrained by common ancestry.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|title=On the Origin of Species|last=Darwin|first=Charles|publisher=|year=1859|isbn=|location=|pages=206}}</ref><ref name=":0" /> [[File:Homology vertebrates-en.svg|thumb|Homologous bone structure in forelimbs of four vertebrates.|159x159px]] * All vertebrates share a homologous eye structure that effectively have a [[Blind spot (vision)|blind spot]] in them where the [[optic nerve]] attaches to the [[retina]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Blind Watchmaker|last=Dawkins|first=Richard|publisher=|year=1986|isbn=978-0-393-31570-7|location=|pages=|url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/blindwatchmaker0000dawk}}</ref>
== Tests for phylogenetic inertia in study systems == There have been several studies that have been able to effectively test for phylogenetic inertia when looking into shared traits; predominantly with a comparative methods approach.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Diniz-Filho|first=Jose Alexandre Felizola|last2=Sant'Ana|first2=Carlos Eduardo Ramos de|last3=Bini|first3=Luis Mauricio|date=1998-01-01|title=An Eigenvector Method for Estimating Phylogenetic Inertia|jstor=2411294|journal=Evolution|volume=52|issue=5|pages=1247–1262|doi=10.2307/2411294|pmid=28565378}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Pienaar|first=Jason|last2=Ilany|first2=Amiyaal|last3=Geffen|first3=Eli|last4=Yom-Tov|first4=Yoram|date=2013-05-01|title=Macroevolution of life-history traits in passerine birds: adaptation and phylogenetic inertia|journal=Ecology Letters|volume=16|issue=5|pages=571–576|doi=10.1111/ele.12077|pmid=23489254|issn=1461-0248}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Morales|first=Eduardo|date=2000-04-01|title=Estimating Phylogenetic Inertia in Tithonia (asteraceae): A Comparative Approach|journal=Evolution|volume=54|issue=2|pages=475–484|doi=10.1111/j.0014-3820.2000.tb00050.x|pmid=10937224|issn=1558-5646}}</ref> Some have used comparative methods and found evidence for certain traits attributed to adaptation, and some to phylogeny; there were also numerous traits that could be attributed to both.<ref name=":2" /> Another study developed a new method of comparative examination that showed to be a powerful predictor of phylogenetic inertia in a variety of situations. It was called Phylogenetic [[Eigenvalues and eigenvectors|Eigenvector]] Regression (PVR), which runs [[Principal component analysis|principal component analyses]] between species on a pairwise [[Distance matrices in phylogeny|phylogenetic distance matrix]].<ref name=":1" /> In another, different study, the authors described methods for measuring phylogenetic inertia, looked at effectiveness of various comparative methods, and found that different methods can reveal different aspects of drivers. [[Autoregression]] and PVR showed good results with morphological traits.<ref name=":3" />
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Orphan|date=August 2016}}
'''FAM63B''' is a [[protein]] which in humans is encoded by the [[gene]] FAM63B. This gene is highly expressed in humans. The FAM63B gene is also highly conserved throughout evolutionary history. The discovered function of FAM63B is an interaction with the kinesin-1 light chain and the transportation of [[Vaccinia|vaccinia virus]] from the nucleus to the cell periphery.
== Gene ==
=== Locus === FAM63B is located at 15q21.3-q22.1,<ref>{{cite web|title=UCSC Genome Browser|url=https://genome.ucsc.edu/cgi-bin/hgTracks?db=hg38&lastVirtModeType=default&lastVirtModeExtraState=&virtModeType=default&virtMode=0&nonVirtPosition=&position=chr15%3A58770007-58856406&hgsid=491653739_Mbxka4ZJG2vt43tYvakMCyt1i2AF}}</ref> spanning 90,707 base pairs on [[chromosome 15]].<ref name="nih.gov">{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene?LinkName=nuccore_gene&from_uid=1003088783|title=FAM63B family with sequence similarity 63 member B [Homo sapiens (human)] - Gene - NCBI|work=nih.gov}}</ref>
[[File:FAM63B locus.jpg|FAM63B locus]]
=== Alternative Names === The full name of FAM63B is family with sequence similarity 63, member B.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.genecards.org/cgi-bin/carddisp.pl?gene=FAM63B&keywords=FAM63B|website=GeneCards|title=Aliases for FAM63B Gene}}</ref> FAM63B is also listed by its alias, KIAA1164, in some publications.<ref>https://www.genecards.org/cgi-bin/carddisp.pl?gene=FAM63B&keywords=FAM63B</ref>
== mRNA ==
=== Isoforms === The FAM63B gene encodes a primary transcript that can be alternatively spliced into 9 protein variants. FAM63B variant a is the most common isoform found in humans.<ref name="nih.gov"/> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Variant !! Length ([[amino acids]]) !! [[Exon]] Count !! Molecular Weight ([[Kilodalton|kdal]]) !! [[Isoelectric Point]] |- | a || 621 || 9 || 67.1 || 4.24 |- | b || 620 || 9 || 67.0 || 4.24 |- | x1 || 639 || 10 || 69.2 || 4.40 |- | x2 || 638 || 10 || 69.1 || 4.40 |- | x3 || 605 || 10 || 65.2 || 4.41 |- | x4 || 587 || 9 || 63.1 || 4.25 |- | x5 || 364 || 6 || 38.0 || 4.50 |- | x6 || 351 || 8 || 40.2 || 4.72 |- | x7 || 342 || 8 || 39.1 || 4.45 |}<ref name="sdsc.edu">http://seqtool.sdsc.edu/CGI/BW.cgi#{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}!</ref>
== Protein ==
=== Structure === [[File:FAM63B protein structure.jpg|thumb|right|Structure of FAM63B protein showing the domain of unknown function, bipartite tryptophan binding motif, hydrophobic stretchm, and KDEL signal.]]
==== Primary Structure ==== FAM63B is a member of the [[Pfam]] super family, and contains a domain of unknown function (DUF544) that is homologous within the protein family.<ref name="nih.gov"/> FAM63B protein variant an also contains a [[wikt:bipartite|bipartite]] tryptophan binding motif from W476 to W533.<ref>Dodding, M. P., Mitter, R., Humphries, A. C., & Way, M. (2011). A [[Kinesin|kinesin-1]] binding motif in [[vaccinia]] virus that is widespread throughout the human genome. The EMBO Journal, 30(22), 4523–4538. http://doi.org/10.1038/emboj.2011.326</ref> Variant a of the protein also contains a hydrophobic stretch of alanine from 567 to 574 and a mixed charge sequence from residue 598 to 617.<ref name="sdsc.edu"/> FAM63B protein may contain a signal sequence specifying return to the endoplasmic reticulum (KDEL) from residue 607 to 621 in variant a.
==== Secondary Structure ==== The secondary structure of FAM63B is a combination of coils, some [[α-helices]], and few [[β-sheets]].<ref name="sdsc.edu"/><ref name="ic.ac.uk">{{cite web|url=http://www.sbg.bio.ic.ac.uk/phyre2/phyre2_output/af64ab84316a975b/summary.html|title=Phyre 2 Results for Undefined|work=ic.ac.uk}}{{Dead link|date=December 2019 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://zhanglab.ccmb.med.umich.edu/I-TASSER/|title=I-TASSER server for protein structure and function prediction|work=umich.edu}}</ref> The Phyre 2 program predicts α-helices in 23% of the protein, β-strands in 9% of the protein, and the remaining 59% of the protein as disordered.<ref name="ic.ac.uk"/> The disordered regions coincide with the coiled regions predicted by other programs, and this results in the long stretch of coiled protein beginning at the N-terminus. According to the SOUSI program, there is a 16-amino acid-long span from residues 265 to 280 of FAM63B that could be a transmembrane sequence.<ref name="expasy.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.expasy.org/proteomics/post-translational_modification|title=ExPASy: SIB Bioinformatics Resource Portal - Categories|work=expasy.org}}</ref> However, transmembrane sequences generally need to be at least 20 amino acids long in order to be stable in the membrane, so a transmembrane sequence is unlikely. Therefore, FAM63B is not fixed in the membrane of any organelle and is free to move through the cell and between organelles.
==== Tertiary Structure ==== Not much is known about the tertiary structure of FAM63B. A predicted folding is shown. [[File:FAM63B tertiary structure.jpg|thumb|none|Predicted protein structure of FAM63B as determined by iTASSER.]]
=== Post-translational Modifications === Post-translational modifications of the FAM63B protein.<ref name="expasy.org"/> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Post-translational Modification !! Site(s) !! Impact on Protein |- | [[Acetylation]] || Ser3 || Stability, localization, metabolism, apoptosis, ribosome recognition for synthesis |- | [[Glycation|Lysine Glycation]] || Lys88, Lys251, Lys280, Lys282, Lys332, Lys393, Lys398, Lys454, Lys547 || Impaired function, changed characteristics |- | [[Phosphorylation]] || Ser7, Ser21, Ser25, Ser26, Ser62, Ser66, Ser68, Ser72, Ser90, Ser94, Ser111, Ser148, Ser153, Ser158, Ser160, Ser165, Ser170, Ser175, Ser188, Ser193, Ser233, Ser396, Ser440, Ser499, Ser541, Ser558, Ser587, Ser589, Ser590, Ser594, Ser597, Thr48, Thr255, Thr344, Thr453, Tyr505 || Conformation change, turn enzymatic activity on/off |- | [[Picornavirales|Picornaviral Cleavage]] || Glu195, Gln535 || Cleavage of polyprotein, degradation |- | [[O-GlcNAc]] || Ser3, Ser21, Ser49, Ser62, Ser66, Ser68, Ser80, Ser152, Ser153, Ser158, Ser170, Ser499, Ser575, Ser587, Ser589, Ser590, Thr144, Thr576 || Nucleocytoplasmic location |}
=== Subcellular Location === FAM63B has predicted NES ([[nuclear export signals]]) at Val274 and Leu277.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbs.dtu.dk/cgi-bin/webface2.fcgi?jobid=5716AACA000019874EC1B1F0&wait=20|title=5716AACA000019874EC1B1F0 expired|work=dtu.dk}}</ref> Also, a NLS ([[nuclear localization signal]]) is predicted for FAM63B at RKRK at residue 599.<ref name="expasy.org" /> In agreement, Reinhardt's method for cytoplasmic/nuclear discrimination predicts FAM63B to be located in the nucleus with a reliability of 76.7%. The presence of both NLS and NES signals and [[O-GlcNAc]] post-translational modification of FAM63B supports the protein's location in both the nucleus and cytoplasm and the discovered protein function as a shuttle for vaccinia virus between the nucleus and the cell periphery.
== Expression ==
=== Expression Level === FAM63B has moderately-high to high expression and is constitutively expressed. FAM63B is likely [[ubiquitously]] expressed in humans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/UniGene/clust.cgi?UGID=2060133&TAXID=9606&SEARCH=FAM63B|title=Family with sequence similarity 63, member B (FAM63B)|work=nih.gov}}</ref>
=== Differential Expression === Expression of FAM63B is high in the embryonic stem cells and differentiated tissues but low or off in [[Embryoid body|embryoid bodies]] and other [[Progenitor cell|progenitor]] cells, such as the [[multipotent]] [[mesenchymal stem cells]]. It is likely that FAM63B is expressed during [[pluripotency]] and [[unipotency]] but is not important for differentiation, as is occurring in embryoid bodies, mesenchymal stem cells, and other progenitor cells. {{multiple image | align = none | direction = horizontal | background color = | total_width = 900 | caption_align = left | image1 = FAM63B GEO data 1.jpg | width1 = 300 | height1 = 300 | alt1 = | link1 = | caption1 = Differential FAM63B expression between human embryonic stem cells, hES-derived embryoid bodies, and hES-derived pancreatic cells. | image2 = FAM63B GEO data 2.jpg | width2 = 300 | height2 = 300 | alt2 = | link2 = | caption2 = Differential FAM63B expression between stromal cells from umbilical cord blood and mesenchymal stem cells. | image3 = FAM63B GEO data 3.jpg | width3 = 300 | height3 = 300 | alt3 = | link3 = | caption3 = Differential FAM63B expression between amniotic fluid kidney-progenitor podocytes and differentiated podocytes. | footer_background = | footer_align = left | footer = Profiles from NCBI UniGene show the expression of FAM63B in stem cell, embryoid body, and differentiated tissues. }}
=== Regulation of Expression ===
==== Transcriptional Regulation ==== The promoter of FAM63B is GXP_5885, located on the positive strand of chromosome 15 from (58770692, 58771462) and is 711 base pairs long.<ref name="genomatix.de">{{cite web|url=https://www.genomatix.de/cgi-bin//eldorado/eldorado.pl?s=40f88fb88bb64f3f83263645b98dcf85;SHOW_ANNOTATION=FAM63B;ELDORADO_VERSION=E30R1410|title=Genomatix: Annotation & Analysis|work=genomatix.de}}</ref>
== Interacting Proteins == FAM63B is shown to interact with one protein, [[KLC1|KLC-1]].<ref name="auto">Dodding, M. P., Mitter, R., Humphries, A. C., & Way, M. (2011). A kinesin-1 binding motif in vaccinia virus that is widespread throughout the human genome. The EMBO Journal, 30(22), 4523–4538. http://doi.org/10.1038/emboj.2011.326</ref> KLC-1, kinesin light chain 1, is a protein which recruits kinesin-1 via its cargo binding light chain and contains a bipartite tryptophan binding motif.<ref name="auto"/> This motif is present in a vaccinia virus integral membrane protein, A36, that is required for transport of the virus from the perinuclear space to the cell periphery.<ref name="auto"/> In the absence of A36, proteins with a bipartite tryptophan binding motif can interact with the kinesin light chain, recruit KLC-1, and promote virus transport from the nucleus to the cytoplasm.<ref name="auto"/>
== Function == The discovered function of FAM63B protein is a transporter of vaccinia virus in the human genome. FAM63B contains a bipartite tryptophan binding motif between W476 and W533.<ref name="auto"/> The motif also contains a [[Glutamine|Q residue]] at the +2 position, which was found to be a frequent occurrence in proteins that bind KLC-1 or KLC-2.<ref name="auto"/> FAM63B is among proteins studied that can rescue virus transport to the cell periphery when expressed in A36-deficient cells, successfully replacing the cytoplasmic domain A36 of vaccinia.<ref name="auto"/>
== Clinical Significance ==
=== Pathology === The specific pathology of FAM63B is unknown.
=== Disease Association === FAM63B is part of four networks regulated by miRNA, three of which are linked to neuronal differentiation and [[dopaminergic]] gene expression.<ref name="auto1">Aberg, K. A., et al. (2014). Methylome-Wide Association Study of Schizophrenia. JAMA Psychiatry, 71(3), 255–264. http://doi.org/10.1001/jamapsychiatry.2013.3730</ref> These findings indicate that FAM63B could be used as a biomarker for the detection and treatment of [[schizophrenia]].<ref name="auto1"/> Furthermore, aberrant methylation of FAM63B may play a role in the development of schizophrenia.<ref name="auto1"/> FAM63B has also been ranked 13 of 25 on a list of associated genes relevant to [[arthritis]].<ref>Li, C., et al. (2008). A systematic method for mapping multiple loci: An application to construct a genetic network for rheumatoid arthritis. Gene, 408(1–2), 104–111. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.gene.2007.10.028</ref>
== Homology ==
=== Paralogs === FAM63B has one paralog, [[FAM63A]], which is a gene of unknown function. FAM63A gene encodes a protein that is 469 amino acids long and 76% similar to FAM63B.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/55793|title=FAM63A family with sequence similarity 63 member A [Homo sapiens (human)] - Gene - NCBI|work=nih.gov}}</ref>
=== Orthologs === FAM63B has been found in all multicellular and unicellular eukaryotes, including plants but excluding protists and fungi. The gene has also been found in archaea but not bacteria.<ref name="nih.gov1">{{cite web|url=http://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/Blast.cgi|title=BLAST: Basic Local Alignment Search Tool|work=nih.gov}}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Genus & species !! Common Name !! Date of Divergence from Humans (MYA) !! Accession Number !! Sequence Length (amino acids) !! Sequence Similarity to Human Protein (%) !! === Distant Homologs === The most distant homolog of FAM63B is found in ''Thermoplasmatales archaeon'', an [[archaea]] that diverged from the human gene 4.25 billion years ago.<ref name="nih.gov1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://timetree.org/search/pairwise/9606/215775?|title=TimeTree|work=timetree.org}}</ref>
=== Homologous Domains === FAM63B is a member of the Pfam super family, and contains a domain of unknown function (DUF544) homologous within the protein family.<ref name="nih.gov1"/> This region of the protein is highly conserved through FAM63B homologs, as is the bipartite tryptophan binding motif of FAM63B and the C-terminus signal sequence.
=== Phylogeny === The phylogenetic tree below shows a time calibration for the evolution of FAM63B. [[File:FAM63B phylogenic tree.jpg|thumb|none|The phylogenetic tree from TimeTree shows a time calibration for the evolution of FAM63B among humans (Has), prairie voles (Moc), polar bears (Uma), Western clawed frogs (Xtr), and Western Indian Ocean coelacanth (Latimeria chalumnae, Lch). The fish is the most diverged, followed by the amphibian, and the mammals, especially humans, are the least diverged. This is as expected in accordance with the evolutionary history of organisms on Earth, and FAM63B shows no great exception to the rule.]]
