'''Presumption of guilt''' is the principle that one is considered guilty unless proven innocent: thus the burden of proof is on the accused, not the accuser.<ref>legal dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/presumption+of+guilt</ref> Presumption of guilt is a denial of an international [[human right]] under Article 11 of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]].<ref name="UDHR">https://www.un.org/en/universal-declaration-human-rights/</ref> Under the presumption of guilt, the [[legal burden of proof]] is thus on the [[Public defender|defense]], which must collect and present compelling evidence to the trier of fact. Presumption of guilt shifts the [[burden of proof (law)|burden of proof]] onto the defendant, who must then prove their [[Innocent|innocence]] in order to achieve [[acquittal]].<ref>''A digest of the law of evidence in criminal cases'' W. Benning & Company, 1846</ref>
==Definition== In [[criminal law]], [[Blackstone's ratio]] is the idea that it is better that ten guilty persons escape than that one innocent suffer,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/blackstone-commentaries-on-the-laws-of-england-in-four-books-vol-2/simple|title=Commentaries on the laws of England|publisher=J.B. Lippincott Co., Philadelphia, 1893}}</ref> as expressed by the English jurist [[William Blackstone]] in ''[[Commentaries on the Laws of England]]'', published in the 1760s. The idea subsequently became a staple of legal thinking in [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] jurisdictions and continues to be a topic of debate.
The phrase "presumption of guilt" has been in use since at least the 1840s.<ref>T. C. Granger. ''A digest of the law of evidence in criminal cases'' W. Benning & Company, 1846</ref>
According to [[Herbert L. Packer]], "It would be a mistake to think of the presumption of guilt as the opposite of the [[presumption of innocence]] that we are so used to thinking of as the polestar of the criminal process and which... occupies an important position in the [[due process|Due Process Model]]."<ref name="Two Models">{{cite journal|last = Packer| first = Herbert L.| author-link = Herbert L. Packer| title = TWO MODELS OF THE CRIMINAL PROCESS| journal = University of Pennsylvania Law Review| volume = 113| issue = 1| pages = 1–68| publisher = University of Pennsylvania| location = Pennsylvania| date = November 1964| language = English| url = https://scholarship.law.upenn.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=6428&context=penn_law_review | doi = 10.2307/3310562| jstor = 3310562}}</ref> The presumption of guilt prioritizes speed and efficiency over reliability, and prevails when [[due process]] is absent.<ref name="Two Models" />
==Typology==
Presumption of guilt may take differing forms:
* [[Collective guilt]], for example the belief that 'all Muslims are terrorists';<ref>[[Spencer Case]], 'Islamist Terror and Collective Guilt', [[national Review]], 4 April 2016</ref> conversely, the terrorist may believe his victims to be collectively guilty of some perceived injustice, as in the case of [[9/11]]. A belief in [[Jewish deicide]] expresses the view that 'all Jews are Christ-killers',<ref>Peter J Tomson, ''Presumed Guilty: How the Jews were Blamed For the Death of Jesus'', Fortress Press, 2003</ref> * Rushing to [[judgement]], for example equating arrest with conviction.<ref>[[Luke Gittos]], '[[Eric Bellquist]] and the presumption of innocence', ''[[Spiked (magazine)|Spiked]]'', 2017-08-17</ref> * The obtaining of a [[false confession]] under [[duress]] or [[torture]].<ref>Japan Times, 'Justice system flawed by presumed guilt', Keiji Hirano, 13/10/2005</ref> * A [[frameup]], usually an admission presumably made under duress. All such admissions should be treated with skepticism without actual video or a signed statement.<ref>Japan Times, 'Justice system flawed by presumed guilt' Keiji Hirano, 13/10/2005</ref> * A [[plea bargain]], which in the worst case may induce a guilty party to give [[false testimony]] against an innocent co-accused.<ref>Washington Post, [https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/why-innocent-people-plead-guilty/2018/01/12/e05d262c-b805-11e7-a908-a3470754bbb9_story.html How to make an innocent plead guilty], Jeffrey Stein, 12/1/2018</ref> * A [[fixed penalty notice]] or on-the-spot fine.<ref>Gotham Gazette, 'With parking tickets, New Yorkers are guilty until proven innocent', Emily Jane Goodman, 7/10/2010</ref> * [[Pre-crime]] policies such as [[preventive detention]].<ref>New York Review, 'How internment became legal', John Townsend Rich, 22/6/2017</ref>
==Motivation==
* [[Racial prejudice]]<ref>Bryan Stevenson, 'A presumption of guilt', [[The New York Review]], 13 July 2017</ref> * Impatience and fear of jurors<ref name=Keith_Findley>Keith Findley, 'The presumption of Innocence exists in theory, not reality', [[Washington Post]], 19/1/2016</ref>{{clarify|date=February 2018}} * "[[Media frenzy]]"<ref name=Keith_Findley /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/384/333.html|title=FindLaw's United States Supreme Court case and opinions.|website=Findlaw|language=en-US|access-date=2019-11-30}}</ref> * A "punitive culture"<ref name=Keith_Findley />{{clarify|date=February 2018}} * [[Cognitive bias]]<ref name=Keith_Findley /><ref>Bryan Stevenson, 'A presumption of guilt', [[The New York Review]], 13 July 2017</ref><ref>https://www.americanbar.org/groups/judicial/publications/judges_journal/2015/fall/cognitive_bias_and_its_impact_on_expert_witnesses_and_the_court/</ref> * [[mind games|Psychological game-playing]]<ref>[[Wayne Dyer]], ''[[Your Erroneous Zones]]'', Warner Books, 1976, p 100</ref><ref>[[Eric Berne]], ''[[Games People Play (book)]]'', Penguin 1964, pp 73-75</ref> * [[Apocalypticism]]<ref>[[Jonathan Schell]], ''[[The Fate of the Earth]]'', Picador, 1982, p133</ref><ref>John Michael Greer, ''Apocalypse'', Quercus, 2012, pp 35, 36, 198</ref>
==Examples in History== Between 1947 and 1956, many US citizens were accused of being communist agents or sympathisers and had their careers ruined during the era of [[McCarthyism]] and the [[Second Red Scare]]. The McCarthyites never proved any of it in court.<ref>[[Don E Carleton]] and [[John Henry Faulk]], ''Red Scare: Right-Wing Hysteria, Fifties Fanaticism, and Their Legacy in Texas'', University of Texas Press, 2014, p. x</ref>
In 1989, [[Ayatollah Khomeini]], supreme leader of [[Iran]], pronounced a death sentence by [[fatwa]] on [[Salman Rushdie]] and anyone assisting publication of his book, ''[[The Satanic Verses]]''; "I call on all Muslims wherever they may be in the world to kill them without delay". The fatwa was condemned for violating [[national sovereignty]], [[freedom of speech]], and the Muslim principle of [[fiqh]].<ref>[[Newsweek]], 27 February 1989</ref>
== Examples in sexual violence and harassment == The American actor and producer [[Jeremy Piven]] has spoken out against the [[Me Too movement]], which, he claims, "put lives in jeopardy without a hearing, due process or evidence". Writing about Piven's comment, journalist [[Brendan O'Neill (journalist)|Brendan O'Neill]], suggests that the presumption of innocence, which barrister and writer [[John Mortimer]] described as a "golden thread", is being weakened.<ref>[[Brendan O'Neill (journalist)|Brendan O'Neill]], [http://www.latimes.com/opinion/op-ed/la-oe-oneill-presumption-innocent-sex-harassment-20171116-story.html "Whatever Happened to the Presumption of Innocence?"], ''Los Angeles Times'', 16 November 2017. Accessed 6 February 2018.</ref>
High Court judge Sir [[Richard Henriques]] has criticized UK police training and methods which allegedly assert that "only 0.1% of rape allegations are false", and in which all complainants are treated as "victims" from the start. In three cases which later collapsed, including those of Liam Allan and Danny Kay, police withheld vital evidence from the defence.<ref>[[Marco Giannangeli]], [https://www.express.co.uk/news/uk/896348/police-rape-case-collapse-high-court-judge-officer-training-presumption-of-guilt "Police must stop training 'Presumption of Guilt', says High Court judge"], ''Daily Express'', 24 December 2017. Accessed 6 February 2018.</ref> It is difficult to assess the true prevalence of [[False accusation of rape|false rape allegations]], but it is generally agreed that rape accusations are false about 2% to 10% of the time.<ref>DiCanio, M. ''The encyclopedia of violence: origins, attitudes, consequences''. New York: Facts on File, 1993. {{ISBN|978-0-8160-2332-5}}.</ref><ref>Lisak, David; Gardinier, Lori; Nicksa, Sarah C.; Cote, Ashley M. (2010). [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/1077801210387747 "False Allegations of Sexual Assualt [sic]: An Analysis of Ten Years of Reported Cases"] (PDF). ''Violence Against Women''. 16 (12): 1318–1334. Accessed 7 February 2018.</ref>
==Internationally== In [[Japan]] the criminal justice system has been criticized for its wide use of [[Detention (imprisonment)|detentions]], during which suspects were forced to make false confessions during interrogations.<ref>[[Keiji Hirano]], "Justice system flawed by presumed guilt", ''[[The Japan Times]]'', 13 October 2005</ref>

{{Hatnote|This article discusses bias in a political context. For bias in other contexts see [[Bias]]. }}
{{Politics}}
'''Political bias''' is a [[bias]] or perceived bias involving the slanting and altering of information to make a political position or [[political candidate]]s seem more attractive. With a distinct association to [[media bias]], it commonly refers to how a reporter, news organization, or TV show covers [[political candidate]]s and policy issues.<ref name=":1" /> Bias emerges in a political context when individuals engage an inability or unwillingness to understand a politically opposing point of view. Such bias in individuals may have roots in each individual's [[Trait theory|traits]] and thinking styles, and it is not clear whether individuals at particular positions along the political spectrum are more biased than any other individuals.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Vyse |first=Stuart |author-link=Stuart Vyse|date=2019 |title=Who Are More Biased: Liberals or Conservatives? |url=https://skepticalinquirer.org/exclusive/who_are_more_biased_liberals_or_conservatives/?/specialarticles/show/who_are_more_biased_liberals_or_conservatives |magazine=[[Skeptical Inquirer]] |volume=43 |issue=4 |pages=24–27|access-date=22 October 2019}}</ref> Political Bias exists beyond simple presentation and understanding of view-points favouring a particular political leader or party, but rather transcends into the readings and interactions among individuals undertaken on a daily basis.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Gentzknow|first=Matthew|last2=Shapiro|first2=Jesse|last3=Stone|first3=Daniel|date=2014|title=Media Bias in the Marketplace: Theory|url=|journal=NBER Paper|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The prevalence of political bias has a lasting impact with proven effects on voter behaviour and consequent political outcomes.<ref name=":0" /> With an understanding of Political Bias, comes acknowledgement of its violation of expected political neutrality.<ref name=":9" /> Lack of Political Neutrality is the result of political bias and further the control mechanism to reduce political bias.<ref name=":9" />
__TOC__
== Types of bias in a political context==
[[Bias|Concision bias]]: Refers to perspective reporting that covers views that are quickly explained ad lends little to no time to [[unconventional]], difficult to explain views.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://courses.lumenlearning.com/boundless-politicalscience/chapter/media-bias/|title=Media Bias|website=Boundless Political Science}}</ref> Concision bias aims to increase communication by selectively focusing on the important information and eliminating redundancy.<ref name=":1" /> In a political context this can mean the omission of seemingly unnecessary details, however, those of which can actually constitute bias in itself, depending which information is determined unnecessary.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Saez-Trumper|first=Diego|date=|title=Gatekeeping, Coverage and Statement bias|url=|journal=Social Media News Communities|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Political opinions are often reduced to a simple party understanding or belief system, with other challenging information excluded in its presentation.<ref name=":1" />
Coverage bias: When topics and issues are addresses by political parties to different extents.<ref name=":2" /> This makes certain issues seem more prevalent and presenting ideas as more important and necessary.<ref name=":2" /> In a political atmosphere this is relevant in the presentation of policies and the issues that they are designed to address, along with the actual coverage time from media and politicians<ref name=":2" />
[[Confirmation bias|Confirmation bias:]] a cognitive bias that favours and seeks information which affirms pre-existing beliefs and opinions.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Plous|first=Scott|date=1993|title=Confirmation Bias|url=|journal=The Psychology of Judgement and Decision Making|volume=|pages=233|via=}}</ref> When set in political atmosphere, individuals with likeminded political beliefs will seek and affirm their opinions, discounting contradictory information<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shermer|first=Michael|date=2006|title=The Political Brain|url=|journal=Scientific American|volume=295|issue=1|pages=36|bibcode=2006SciAm.295a..36S|doi=10.1038/scientificamerican0706-36|pmid=16830675}}</ref> A recent meta-analysis attempted to compare levels of confirmation bias among liberals and conservatives in the United States and found that both groups were roughly equally biased.<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/1745691617746796|title = At Least Bias Is Bipartisan: A Meta-Analytic Comparison of Partisan Bias in Liberals and Conservatives|journal = Perspectives on Psychological Science|volume = 14|issue = 2|pages = 273-291|year = 2018|last1 = Ditto|first1 = Peter H.|last2 = Liu|first2 = Brittany S.|last3 = Clark|first3 = Cory J.|last4 = Wojcik|first4 = Sean P.|last5 = Chen|first5 = Eric E.|last6 = Grady|first6 = Rebecca H.|last7 = Celniker|first7 = Jared B.|last8 = Zinger|first8 = Joanne F.}}</ref>
[[False consensus effect|False consensus bias]]: Exists when the normalisation of an individual's opinions, beliefs and values are believed to be common.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071117094105/http://www.psychologycampus.com/social-psychology/false-consensus.html|title=False Consensus and False Uniqueness|website=Psychology Campus|access-date=2019-05-15}}</ref> This bias exists in a group setting where the collective group opinion is attributed to the wider population, with little to now inter group challenges.<ref name=":1" /> This is the basis of political party formation and engages the ongoing attempt to [[Normalization (sociology)|normalise]] these views within the wider population with little recognition to the different beliefs outside the party.<ref name=":2" />
[[wikt:speculative#Adjective|Speculative content]]: When stories focus on what has the potential to occur with speculative phrasing such as “may”, “what if” and “could” rather than focusing on the factual evidence of what has and/or definitely will occur<ref name=":10" />'''.''' This further speculative bias when the piece is not specifically labelled as an opinion and analysis article.<ref name=":2" /> This occurs in a political context particularly in the introduction of policies or the addressing of opposing policies.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1080/08838157809363907|title = Bias in television news coverage of political events: A methodological analysis|journal = Journal of Broadcasting|volume = 22|issue = 4|pages = 517–530|year = 1978|last1 = Hofstetter|first1 = C. Richard|last2 = Buss|first2 = Terry F.}}</ref> This bias allows parties to make their policies more appealing and appear to address issues more directly, by speculating the positive and negative outcomes.<ref name=":5" />
Gatekeeping bias: This type of bias exists through the use of [[ideological]] selection, deselection and/or omission of stories based on individualised opinions.<ref name=":5" /> Similarly related to agenda bias, existing primarily when the focus is on politicians and how they choose to cover and present preferred policy discussions and issues.<ref name=":2" />
[[Partisan bias on Wikipedia|Partisan bias]]: Exists in the media when reporters serve and create leaning of a particular political party.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Soroka|first=Stuart|date=2016|title=Gatekeeping and Negativity Bias|url=|journal=Political Communication|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Political neutrality== [[Political neutrality]] is the counteraction for political bias, looking to ensure the ability of public servants to carry out any official duties in an impartial manner, relative to their political beliefs.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Kernaghan|first=Kenneth|date=1986|title=Political Rights and Political Neutrality: finding the bland point|url=|journal=Canadian Public Administration|volume=|pages=639–652|via=}}</ref> In areas such as media coverage, legal and bureaucratic decisions and academic teachings, the need for taking corrective action against politically biased actions is the foundation of political neutrality enforcement.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Yair|first=Omer|date=2018|title=When do we care about political neutrality? The hypocritical nature of reaction to political bias|url=|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Research suggests that political neutrality is favoured over political bias, with [[Republican Party (United States)|Republicans]], [[Independent politician|Independents]] and [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democrats]]' preferring to get their news sources from politically neutral media.<ref name=":9" /> Individuals responses to political bias and motivations are challenged when the engagement of bias furthers and assists their political party or ideology.<ref name=":9" /> The denunciation of political neutrality itself elicits a more aggravated response, directly controlling a normative acceptance of Political Bias.<ref name=":9" /> Limitations of [https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0196674 political neutrality] exist regarding [[media coverage]] and generate accusations for any actions or messages perceived as politically biased.<ref name=":7" /> Biases remain embedded in contextual intergroup competition, meaning political considerations based on action or message can challenge specific ideologies or further enhance and advance an ideology.<ref name=":9" />
== Political bias and framing== Political bias exists primarily in the concept of framing.<ref name=":2" /> [[Framing (social sciences)|Framing]] is the social construction of political or social movements in a positive or negative representation.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Sheufele|first=Dietram|date=1999|title=Framing as a Theory of Media Effects|url=|journal=Journal of Communication|volume=49|pages=|via=}}</ref> Political bias in this context is political leaders and parties presenting information to highlight a problem and offering solutions that favour their own political position.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Entman|first=Robert|date=2010|title=Media framing biases and political power: Explaining slant in news of Campaign 2008|url=|journal=Journalism: Theory, Practice and Criticism|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> This makes their personal position appear more favourable and their policies as the expected course of action.<ref name=":3" /> The [[framing effect]] looks at the situations in which people are only presented with options within two frames, one presented negatively and the other positively.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Druckman|first=James|date=2001|title=On the Limits of Framing Effects: Who can Frame?|url=|journal=Political Science|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The framing effect is increasingly significant in opinion polls designed to encourage specific organisations that are commissioned to poll.<ref name=":8" /> If reliable, credible and sufficient information is provided, this bias can be significantly reduced.<ref name=":4" /> Framing further looks at the impact of slanting in political campaigning and its potential impact of the distribution of political power where political bias is present.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Entman|first=Robert|date=2008|title=Media framing biases and political power: Explaining slant in news of Campaign 2008|url=|journal= Journalism: Theory, Practice & Criticism|volume=11|issue=4|pages=389–408|doi=10.1177/1464884910367587}}</ref> Through understanding of Framing as an omnipresent process used in analysis to discern connections between aspects of reality and convey an interpretation of opinions that may not be entirely accurate.<ref name=":8" />
== Evidence of political bias in search engines== Opinions and perceptions of political issues and candidates are often shaped by search results from search engines like google.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.canirank.com/analysis-of-political-bias-in-internet-search-engine-results/|title=Study: Does Google have a Political Bias?|last=Bentley|first=Matt|date=2017}}</ref> [[Google Algorithm updates in 2017|Google algorithms]] are not designed to provide balanced or equal representation of controversial issues.<ref name=":6" /> Search engines influence democracy due to the potential distrust of media, increasing online searches for political information and understanding.<ref name=":6" /> Looking specifically at America, the [[FCC fairness doctrine|Fairness Doctrine]] was introduced in 1949 to avoid political bias in all licensed Broadcasting mediums.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Patterson|first=Thomas|date=2013|title=The News Media: Communicating Political Images|url=|journal=We the People|volume=10|pages=|via=}}</ref> Within the context of [[political polarization|polarizing]] topics such as political bias, the top search results can play a significant role in shaping opinions.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Bernhardt|first=Dan|date=2007|title=Political Polarization and the Electoral Effects of Media Bias|url=|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Through the use of a [https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10791-018-9341-2 bias quantification framework], bias can be measured within the political bias by rank, within the search system but further address the sources of the bias through the input data and ranking system.<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Kulshrestha|first=Juhi|date=2018|title=Search bias quantification: investigating political bias in social media and web search|url=|journal=Information Retrieval Journal|volume=22|issue=1–2|pages=188–227|doi=10.1007/s10791-018-9341-2}}</ref> Within the context of information queries, the search results are determined through a ranking system which in the case of topics such as Politics, can return politically biased search results.<ref name=":13" /> This bias present in the search results can be a direct result of either biased data that collaborates the ranking system or because of the structure of the ranking system itself.<ref name=":13" /> This questionable nature of search results raises questions of impact on users and to what degree the ranking system can impact political opinions and beliefs, which can directly translate into voter behavior.<ref name=":13" /> This can also affirm or encourage biased data within the google search results.<ref name=":13" /> Whilst research has shown that users do not place exclusive trust on the information provided by search engines,<ref name=":13" /> studies have shown that individuals that are undecided politically are susceptible to be manipulated by bias relative to political candidates and the light in which their policies and actions are presented and conveyed.<ref name=":13" /> In the quantification of political bias, both the input data for search results and further the ranking system in which they are presented to the user encapsulate bias to varying degrees.<ref name=":13" />
There is further distinctive political bias present in social media where the algorithm which structures user content, facilitates confirmation bias.<ref name=":13" /> This involves presenting political information dependent on common searches and focuses of the users which further re-affirms political bias and reduces exposure to politically neutral content.<ref name=":13" />
Determining the difference between content and source bias is a significant focus of determining the role of political bias in search engines.<ref name=":13" /> This focus looks directly at the actual content of the information present and whether it is purposefully selective in the information presented, or rather whether the source of the information is projecting personalised opinions relative to their political opinions.<ref name=":13" />
== Political bias in the media== [[Media bias]] highlights political bias in the reporting of political topics and representation of politicians<ref name=":11" />'''.''' Where a reporter emphasises particular points of view and conveys selected information to further their own political view, they present biased information favouring their own [[Freedom of thought|political opinion]].<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Stromberg|first=David|date=2002|title=Mass Media Competition, Political Competition, and Public Policy|url=|journal=Institute for International Economic Studies|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Determining media biases relative to political positioning, there are distinctive regulations which protect against the fabrication of information.<ref name=":12" /> The media, rather, alters the representation of information to promote political positions.<ref name=":14" /> Alteration of political opinions, which directly impact voter behavior and decisions, can be altered under media bias due to the failed representation of information.<ref name=":12" /> This form of political bias has continuing impacts when used to change opinions of others.<ref name=":12" /> Where media remains a powerful information source for political information, it can create political bias in the informational representation of policy issues.<ref name=":12" />[[File:Media Bias Study Table.gif|thumb|Use of media to further political bias]]
An example of quantification of political bias in the media is [[Propaganda model|a propaganda model]], a concept introduced by [[Edward S. Herman]] and [[Noam Chomsky]]. It is a [[political economy]] model, looking at the “manufacturing” of political policies through manipulation of mass media.<ref name=":15">{{Citation|last=Robinson|first=Piers|chapter=Does the Propaganda Model Actually Theorise Propaganda?|date=2018-10-25|pages=53–67|publisher=University of Westminster Press|isbn=9781912656165|doi=10.16997/book27.e|title=The Propaganda Model Today: Filtering Perception and Awareness}}</ref> This model further looked at the capital funding of Media outlets and their ownership, which often relates political ties.<ref name=":15" />
Political bias in the media is also discussed in how social leaders discuss political issues.<ref name=":14" /> To determine the existence of political bias, agenda determination is used.<ref name=":12" /> Agenda determination is designed to provide an understanding of the agenda behind presentation of political issues and attempt to determine the political bias that is present.<ref name=":12" />
Within a 2002 study by [[Jim A. Kuypers]] : ''Press Bias and Politics: How the Media Frame Controversial Issues'',<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Kuypers|first=Jim|date=2002|title=Press Bias and Politics: How the Media Frame Controversial Issues|url=|journal=|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Kuypers looks at the omission of left leaning points of view from the mainstream print press.<ref name=":17" /> Kuypers determined that Politicians would receive positive press coverage only when covering and delivering topics that aligned with press-supported beliefs.<ref name=":17" /> This meant the press were engaging in bias within the media through their coverage and selection/release of political information which was challenging the neutral conveyance of political messages.<ref name=":17" />
David Baron similarly presents a [https://www.wiley.com/en-au/Game+Theory%3A+An+Introduction%2C+2nd+Edition-p-9781118533895 game-theoretic model] of media behaviour,<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Baron|first=David|date=April 2013|title=Game Theory: An Introduction|url=|journal=Wiley|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> suggesting that mass media outlets only hire journalists whose writing is aligned with their political positions.<ref name=":18" /> This engages false consensus bias, as beliefs are determined to be common due to the surrounding of aligned views. This effectively heightens the political bias within media representation of information.<ref name=":18" />
== Attempts to counteract political bias== The [[Media Research Center|Media Research Center]] is an American media watch group, with specific focus on the presence of politically biased content.<ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=https://www.mrc.org/about|title=About the MRC|last=wonder95|date=2015-09-29|website=Media Research Center|access-date=2019-05-30}}</ref> Its stated mission is to “expose and neutralize the propaganda arm of the left”.<ref name=":16" /> The Media Research Center currently operates numerous projects aimed at calling attention to political bias in the media and ensuring it is correctly identified.<ref name=":16" /> More specifically, MRC releases a newsletter called ''CyberAlert'' aimed at profiling any inaccurate reports about politics within the news media, specific to America.<ref name=":16" /> It is written by editor [[Brent Baker]], who further addresses media articles as potentially biased articles by labeling them ''BIASALERT''<ref name=":16" />''.'' The analysis of political bias in the media is determined through collaboration with ''Media Reality Check'', which specifically aims to combat liberal bias and reporting.<ref name=":16" /> In 2005, Media Research Center developed a website called [[Newsbusters|NewsBusters]], which acts as a blog for analysis of stories where political bias has been flagged.<ref name=":16" /> It further operates on a more personal note, not only calling out bias in articles, but further challenging the authors of said articles as to their politically biased writing.<ref name=":16" /> Further in the United States, bias now needs to be disclosed as a conflict of interest when addressing political parties, candidates and policies.<ref name=":19">{{Cite journal|last=Plaisance|first=Patrick|date=August 2006|title=Transparency: An Assessment of the Kantian Roots of a Key Element in Media Ethics Practice|journal=Journal of Mass Media Ethics|volume=21|issue=2&3|pages=|doi=10.1207/jmme.2006.21.issue-2&3|issn=}}</ref> This addresses that individuals will hold different political opinions and have vested interests in different political topics, however that degree of bias must be disclosed so that the conflict of interest and presence of bias is understood.<ref name=":19" /> <br />{{Biases|state=expanded}}{{Navbox | name = Conflict of interest | title = [[Conflict of interest]] | state = {{{state|autocollapse}}} | image = <!--[[File:Chronic pain.jpg|180px]]--> | bodyclass = hlist
